HEADLINE: THE PORK-BELLIES APPROACH TO HOUSING

BYLINE: By Noam Scheiber. 
Noam Scheiber, a senior editor at The New Republic, is writing a biography of Maurice Greenberg, the former head of the insurance company A.I.G.

 BODY:
Six years ago, the story goes, a young Maryland couple named Tom and Lisa Hanlon faced an important, if common, financial decision. Lisa worked for a management consulting firm in Washington, D.C.; Tom was a science teacher at a suburban high school. The Hanlons had spent the previous two years renting an apartment in Bethesda, but Lisa was eager to start building home equity, and Tom reluctantly agreed to test the local market.
The Hanlons' dilemma was as follows: On the one hand, the couple had refined tastes -- topping their list of assets was a $34,000 BMW 328Ci coupe. Tom and Lisa knew their first home wouldn't be their dream home, but they also didn't want to take a step down from their upscale rental. On the other hand, with a combined income of just under $150,000, the Hanlons worried about shouldering more debt than they could handle. Eventually they settled on a nearby development called Grosvenor Park, whose elegant 2,300-square-foot model met Lisa's exacting standards. But the Hanlons' selection came to an uncomfortable $405,000 after upgrades like skylights and a premium lot. To further complicate the picture, home prices in the Washington area were spiraling upward. The Hanlons worried that they could be priced out of the market if they didn't buy right away. 
 As it happens, the Hanlons are a fictional couple, but their home-buying experience is emblematic of a modern financial conundrum and is, in fact, the subject of a case study at Harvard Business School. For the last several years, students in the school's Real Property course have read about the Hanlons' situation, then scrupulously assessed the couple's options. How much would the home have to appreciate in four years to make it a good investment, assuming a 20 percent down payment? What about 5 percent down? Should the Hanlons settle for a more modest house? Should they take their time looking? 
 These are the questions Will Goetzmann, the course's most recent instructor, put to students on this year's final exam. But Goetzmann's exam added a twist that previous classes had not seen. For that matter, neither had any real estate agent, home buyer or most of Goetzmann's Harvard colleagues. Goetzmann's exam posed the following hypothetical about the Hanlons: ''Suppose that housing futures for the D.C. area were available and traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Would it affect their buy-versus-rent decision?'' 
 Housing futures? 
 To the extent that the average person has a mental image of a futures market, it probably involves burly Midwesterners exchanging pork-belly orders in a frenzied trading pit. That picture isn't entirely off base. A futures contract is basically a commitment to buy or sell a product at some prearranged point in time for some prearranged price. So, for example, I might agree to sell you one ton of pork bellies for $2,000 next May. Why would I do that? Suppose I'm a hog farmer and you make bacon. The going rate for a ton of pork bellies today is, say, $1,950, but we both expect it to rise over the next year. Not wanting to push my luck, I might be happy to lock in a gain of $50 per ton. Similarly, you're probably happy to lock in a $50 price increase, given that prices could rise much higher. In a sense, the futures contract allows both of us to buy a little insurance. 
 There's another thing futures markets make possible: speculation. Suppose I'm an investor who thinks the price of pork bellies will rise significantly higher than $2,000 next year. Then maybe I agree to buy at $2,000 so that, when the time comes, I can turn around and sell for well above that amount. (This is known as ''going long.'') Conversely, if I think the price of pork bellies is going to plummet, I can agree to sell them for $2,000 a ton next year, reckoning that at some point before then, I'll be able to buy them much cheaper and pocket the difference. (This is known as ''going short.'')
 Up until about 30 years ago, most futures markets dealt in commodities -- agricultural products and precious metals -- which are susceptible to large price swings. But during the 1970's, futures began to proliferate in progressively more exotic areas, so that today investors can bet on everything from the value of certain economic statistics (like interest rates and inflation) to the weather (say, the likelihood of a snowy winter). As of last May, they can also bet on housing. In principle, the way housing futures work is similar to the way pork-belly futures do, except that investors aren't betting on the prices of individual houses per se but the value of a price index that's updated every month. If I think housing prices in Washington are likely to rise by 10 percent next year, I can place a bet that earns me a profit if I'm right. If I think housing prices are likely to fall, I can place that bet, too. 
 Which brings us back to Tom and Lisa, and Goetzmann's curious exam question. In an ideal world, a couple in the Hanlons' situation might choose not to buy a home for a few more years. Perhaps they can't actually afford to live in Grosvenor Park. Or maybe it isn't a place they plan on staying for very long. The problem is that in order to be able to trade up later on, such a couple would need to parlay the appreciation on their starter home into a down payment on the next one. Hence the urge to buy quickly. 
 The beauty of the futures market is that people like the Hanlons can achieve almost precisely the same outcome without buying the starter home. That is, they can simply take the money they had set aside for a down payment and invest it in housing futures. If Washington-area housing then appreciated, their investment would, too, and by close to the same amount. If housing prices stayed flat or declined, then they would be no worse off, since the same would likely be true of any house they bought. Unlike stocks, which can move down as housing prices move up, an investment in futures will more or less mimic buying a house. 
 In fact, once you start chewing over the benefits of housing futures, the world starts to look a little different. For example, you don't have to live in Washington to invest in the local housing market. You can be in some chronically unsexy market -- a place like Des Moines or Indianapolis -- that would have normally make you a bystander to the recent housing boom. Or conversely, suppose you're one of those Manhattanites who have seen the value of your brownstone triple in the last decade. You'll be retiring soon, and the last thing you need is to have the bottom fall out before you move to Florida. Now, like a risk-averse hog farmer, you can lock in your profits by betting on prices to fall. Or maybe you're a builder in California worried that a new development won't fill up. Suddenly you can hedge your risk and not worry about losing your shirt if the market turns. 
 Of course, if the point of housing futures was to help the odd homeowner in Iowa, or the developer in California, it would be a clever but unremarkable innovation. The real hope is that housing futures will one day make the entire boom-bust cycle of American real estate a thing of the past. But for that to happen, housing futures will have to evolve from a financial novelty into something approaching a household name. And that may be a lot to ask of a market that didn't exist until four months ago. 
 The two men who have made it possible to trade housing on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange -- Sam Masucci, a former Wall Street trader, and Robert Shiller, an eminent Yale economist -- have spent more than a decade laboring to open the residential real estate market to investors. In 2002, they started a small company called MacroMarkets with the aim of creating a futures market.
 For the market to succeed, it needs to become liquid -- which is to say it needs tens of thousands of traders, so that for every buyer there is a seller, and vice versa. Naturally, Shiller and Masucci believe there will be plenty of interest. On the so-called long side (that is, people who bet on home prices rising), they expect a brisk trade from large institutions like pension funds, which have never had a chance to invest in residential real estate before. On the opposite side of the equation, the so-called short side, MacroMarkets expects that any number of institutions, from developers to banks to mortgage lenders, will bet on home prices to sag. 
 Down the road, Masucci and Shiller also hope to entice individual homeowners into the market. That would most likely happen through financial intermediaries, like insurance companies or banks. Those worried about getting priced out of a particular metropolitan area -- the Tom and Lisa Hanlons of the world -- could essentially bet long, buying a product that would pay them a dividend when housing prices appreciated. Other products would pay a dividend when housing prices fell, essentially a short position. 
 A few weeks after housing futures started trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Masucci talked to representatives of major Wall Street banks, among them Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley, and reported that ''95 percent of them were excited'' about housing futures. Only two months later, MacroMarkets was in discussions with roughly a dozen large institutions, mostly investment banks, about licensing the right to sell a host of housing-based financial products. But new futures markets tend to start slowly -- the Mercantile Exchange's weather futures saw only 87 trades in 2000, the first full year, versus close to a million in 2005 -- and housing futures are no different. As of mid-August, only about 2,700 housing contracts had traded, and the market consisted mostly of speculators placing small bets. Fritz Siebel, a broker with Tradition Financial Services, which handles some of the housing-futures business, says the early traders tend to be sophisticated financial service industry professionals who are dabbling in the market.
 This trend could prove troubling. One benefit of futures markets is that they can foreshadow prices months in advance. The hope is that buyers and sellers armed with this information will avoid costly mistakes, like irrationally expecting ever-rising home values, which can lead to real estate bubbles. But a futures market where people make only rapid-fire trades can experience wild swings, potentially unsettling the housing market itself. 
 Still, speculators do serve an important function, and if the housing futures experiment is going to succeed, it will need as many of them as it will longer-term investors and hedgers, who exert a more calming influence. One of the early speculators is a Long Island accountant named Mark Grappel. Grappel says he read about the debut of the housing futures market, and by the second week of trading had begun to monitor the activity. 
 Right now investors can bet on the price of housing in 10 American cities, as well as on a composite index that combines all 10 into a single number. After selecting a city, the next step is to decide on the length of the contract you would like to trade -- 3, 6, 9 or 12 months. Grappel owns a condominium in Fort Lauderdale and has several friends who live in South Florida. He was particularly interested in the Miami market -- in fact, he was convinced it was heading for a fall. So, on June 8, he placed a bet that the Miami index would show a decline by the time his contract came up in November. Over the next two weeks, pessimism about Miami real estate weighed on the city's November contract, putting Grappel up $12,500. But Grappel was nervous. A new reading of the index was due out the following day. It would be the latest measurement of actual prices in Miami, and he wasn't sure what it would show -- prices can rise in a given month even if the long-term trend is down -- let alone how the thinly traded market would react. He decided to liquidate the position and take his profit.
 Grappel may sound like a riverboat gambler, but he illustrates the promise of housing futures. Grappel says he reads widely about Miami real estate -- consulting blogs, local publications, even local data on prices and inventories. He occupies his Fort Lauderdale condo several times a year, and when he's not around, friends serve as his eyes and ears. (Recently a friend in Palm Beach County told Grappel that a nearby house went on the market last year for $890,000 and that the owners rejected an early bid of $830,000; six months later the friend heard the best they could do was $650,000.) Which is to say, when Grappel makes a bet about the direction of housing prices, it's based on an aggregation of a lot of valuable but otherwise diffuse information. Now consider that a fully liquid market would bring together thousands of Mark Grappels -- people with intimate knowledge of a local market and a financial incentive to bet wisely -- and you begin to understand how a futures market could one day forecast price movements with considerable precision. 
 In fact, even though the market is still in its infancy, it has already begun to throw off valuable information. Over the last several weeks, Siebel reports, prices for the 3-, 6-, 9- and 12-month contracts for most cities have begun to trace out discernible curves, known as forward curves, laying out a plausible path for the direction of home prices over the next year. (As of early August, San Francisco typically had the most pronounced downward curve; Denver was more or less flat. The rest of the cities -- like New York and Washington -- tended to lie somewhere in between.) Benson Durham, a research economist at the Federal Reserve Board, has begun tracking the futures to get a handle on the housing market. In a recent paper, Durham notes that following the futures market has become, in terms of reliability, at least as useful as another common method: analyzing the stock prices of companies in the homebuilding sector. 
 The germ of the idea for housing futures dates back to the late 1980's, when Shiller first began collaborating with a Wellesley economist named Karl Case. Case had pioneered an unusually precise method of measuring home prices by comparing back-to-back sales of the same house. Over the next few years, he and Shiller used this data to demonstrate that contrary to popular opinion, home ownership could be a risky proposition, and that home prices could move down for several years at a time, at least in inflation-adjusted terms. (That real estate began to hemorrhage value in several major cities during the early 90's didn't hurt their credibility.) Shiller would later seal his reputation with the book ''Irrational Exuberance,'' which anticipated this decade's stock-market correction. But at the time, he was already preoccupied with the subject of financial risk. Wrestling with ways to alleviate the risk of homeownership naturally led him to consider a futures market. 
 In 1991, Case, Shiller and a former student of Shiller's named Allan Weiss founded a company whose primary objective was to create a futures market in housing. Case Shiller Weiss soon signed an agreement with the Chicago Board of Trade to explore the possibility. But board officials expressed concern about insufficient demand on the long side of the equation and eventually abandoned the idea. By that point, however, Case Shiller Weiss had already been producing housing price data for metropolitan areas all over the country. Selling the so-called Case-Shiller indexes became a multimillion-dollar business.
 Meanwhile, unbeknownst to Shiller and his partners, a small team at Merrill Lynch was kicking around some of the same housing market issues Shiller had identified a few years earlier. Except that they approached the problem from the perspective of Wall Street investors eager to bear some of the risks that average homeowners didn't want (in exchange for some of the rewards, of course). The idea was that Merrill would pay homeowners a small premium every year in exchange for a share of the profits on the eventual sale of their home. Merrill would then turn around and sell off to investors all the claims it had accumulated. To make the project work, the Merrill group realized that it needed ultrafine data on home prices. That's when one of the Merrill traders, Sam Masucci, struck up a relationship with Case Shiller Weiss.
 By 2002, the financial services giant Fiserv had bought Case Shiller Weiss. But Shiller retained the rights to develop financial products based on the company's indexes. Masucci had left Merrill and was contemplating his next move when Shiller suggested that the two give housing futures another shot. The idea of developing housing futures appealed to the real estate man in Masucci. He had worked for his father's homebuilding company during the bear market of the 1980's and figured that developers in those days would have jumped at the chance to hedge their projects. In any case, Masucci had never gotten over his impulse to plant a flag in what, at over $20 trillion, is the economy's largest unexploited asset. MacroMarkets was born.
 This time the futures exchanges were more receptive. In the more than a decade since the Chicago Board of Trade passed on the original proposal, real estate had moved to the front of the country's consciousness. And no one was more eager to highlight this than MacroMarkets. In a PowerPoint presentation that Terry Loebs, one of the company's executives, delivers to potential futures investors, he includes a slide cataloging the number of television shows devoted to real estate. ''There's actually one show called 'Flip This House,' and another show called 'Flip That House,''' Loebs marvels. In mid-2004, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange agreed to partner with Shiller and Masucci and create the country's first housing futures exchange. MacroMarkets would get a tiny cut of every trade.
 Some economists question whether housing futures are really so critical, at least for individuals. Todd Sinai of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School points out that homeownership serves two functions: it provides a flow of services -- that is, a roof over your head -- and it serves as an investment, generating a return on your savings. True, he says, a steep drop in housing prices would hurt the value of your investment. But as long as you stay in the same city, this drop would be more or less offset by the fact that housing, over all, had just become cheaper. A similar logic applies to price increases. As the Harvard economist Edward L. Glaeser notes, ''Owning a house is itself a hedge'' against rising home prices. Though the skeptics concede that futures-based products might attract the occasional small-time customer, they question the scale of the appeal. 
 Even if the product never catches on with individual investors, the futures market could still thrive on business from bigger players, like mortgage lenders and developers. But here, too, there are potential snags. Perhaps the biggest is that housing isn't a commodity the way oil or soybeans are. The price of a house in one neighborhood can fall while the same house in another neighborhood appreciates, to say nothing of the next town over. Because the Mercantile Exchange futures only trade at the metropolitan level, there's no way to deal with these narrower fluctuations. When pressed on this, Shiller and Masucci observed that metro-level price changes do explain roughly half the variation in price for a typical house. Whether that's good enough for hedging purposes remains to be seen. 
 In the end, the way you feel about futures may come down to how much you worry about housing market bubbles. Most economists scream ''bubble'' when buyers bid up prices simply because they expect prices to rise further, not because those increases are justified by supply and demand. Unlike a run-of-the-mill price drop, the popping of a bubble can be a brutally painful affair, creating a domino effect of mortgage defaults, bankruptcies, tight credit and, ultimately, a regionwide recession. 
 Economists like Sinai and Chris Mayer of Columbia concede that housing prices might look inflated in many parts of the country. But, they argue, the cost of housing in cities like Boston and San Francisco is more or less in line with those cities' historical patterns once you factor in today's low interest rates. ''People in San Francisco have legitimate reasons to believe prices will grow faster than people in the Midwest do, because they have for the last 60 years,'' Mayer says. 
 On the other hand, Shiller's research suggests that the rise in home prices should basically track inflation, and that the aggressive buying of real estate is simply the product of our most recent cultural obsession -- supercharged by the Internet, cable television and bloggers. This may sound extreme, but even such leading lights as Alan Greenspan are beginning to agree. At a speech before the Economic Club of New York in 2005, Greenspan allowed that there may well be a lot of local real estate bubbles, even if there is no national bubble. 
 If you're someone who shares this view, it's not hard to appreciate the wisdom of hedging your home. One such person is an economist named Dean Baker, the co-director of a liberal Washington policy institute called the Center for Economic and Policy Research. As early as 2002, Baker began cranking out memo after memo warning that the country was flirting with a housing bubble. Then, in 2004, Baker took his own advice and sold his condominium in Washington's trendy Adams Morgan neighborhood. Baker and his wife had purchased the condo for $160,000 in 1997 and had seen its value almost triple. ''I would have felt like a fool sitting on it,'' he says, though he now figures he could have made another $10,000 or $20,000 by waiting another year. (Prices have since moderated.) These days the couple lives in a rented apartment only a few blocks from the old place. Occasionally, he gets wistful. I asked Baker if he would have stayed in the apartment and hedged the risk had the option been available. His response: ''We would have done it, absolutely.'' 
 If the ultimate goal of a housing futures market is to dampen the boom-and-bust cycle of the real estate market, then the most important players may not be individual home buyers but developers, home builders and banks. Which is to say, not people who buy homes but the people in the business of supplying them. The big problem with real estate, after all, is that it takes so long for supply to respond to rising prices. Given the lag in data, it's hard to know if prices have changed until months after the fact. It then takes several more months to complete construction on a new development -- years when you factor in the time it takes to purchase land and nail down a permit. By the time a developer is ready to sell, the housing market may have cooled. That several-hundred-unit development -- not to mention all the houses and condos that rivals are building -- may end up flooding the market. 
 As it happens, this is a problem that bedeviled farmers for decades. Prior to the creation of futures markets, the market for hogs was prone to disastrous boom-bust cycles. When hog prices were high, farmers would breed more hogs. But this led to a massive oversupply by the time the hogs were fattened up and taken to market, at which point prices would collapse. It wasn't until the introduction of pork-belly futures in the early 1960's that the wild swings of the economic hog cycle largely disappeared. After that, a hog farmer could consult the market about where prices were most likely headed when he was actually ready to sell. If the futures price was high, he could lock in that price and step up production. If the futures price was low, he could slow production to a trickle and bide his time. The market stabilized because everyone could look ahead and plan production accordingly. 
 Similarly, in the real estate market, developers may soon be consulting futures prices when planning upcoming projects. If the price is high, a developer could move ahead while shorting the futures market as a kind of insurance policy. If the price is low, he might put a few projects on hold. 
 At least one large homebuilder has already entered the futures market. In mid-June, to test how amenable others might be to this arrangement, I met with Lou Minicucci, who runs Northpoint Realty Development with his son-in-law, Eric Loth, and another longtime partner. Northpoint builds middle- and upper-middle-class homes in the Boston suburb of North Andover, about a 30-minute drive from downtown. The company also has a Florida branch that handles projects in Palm Beach County and Fort Lauderdale. 
 I met Minicucci and Loth in a wood-paneled conference room at the company's North Andover headquarters. Around the room's periphery were 8 or 10 scale drawings of developments the company had either recently completed or was in the middle of building. One red-hued rendering depicted a development in downtown Andover, about a mile from the prep school that produced George W. Bush and his father. Loth, a trim blond man with a slight Boston accent, sighed that it took Northpoint six years just to win permits for the site. Another picture showed a 269-unit development abutting a state forest off nearby Route 114. The development still has about 60 unsold units, roughly $19 million worth of housing. But Minicucci, barrel-chested and thick-fingered, pointed out that the project has proceeded in phases. If demand dries up, Northpoint can always put the final phase on hold. 
 When it comes to South Florida, on the other hand, the anxiety is somewhat more palpable. Unlike in Boston, many of the developments in Florida are high-rise buildings that can't be phased in. ''Once you start, you build the whole thing,'' Loth said. And whereas the Boston area's convoluted permitting process tends to scare off large national builders -- who other than a local wants to spend six years haggling with the Andover planning board? -- many parts of South Florida have comparatively few constraints, meaning that the supply of housing can expand seemingly without limit. Even Mayer and Sinai, the bubble skeptics, think the local market might be overvalued.
 On the wall as you enter the Northpoint conference room is a 3-by-4-foot computer-generated drawing of a 21-story tower. This is Strada, a development of about 100 one- and two-bedroom condos three blocks from the major thoroughfare connecting downtown Fort Lauderdale to the Atlantic Ocean. Strada is now almost completely sold out, even though it's still under construction. But across the street, Northpoint has planned a similar, 24-story high-rise building, on which it has yet to break ground. Up until about 2005, Loth says, prices in South Florida moved up almost week to week. But over the last year, ''things have cooled off from the hyperkinetic pace,'' he says, adding, ''Things are sitting a little longer.'' The concern is that overbuilding in the area could begin to drag down prices. 
 Loth is a former bond trader with Charles Schwab in Denver. He recently read about the housing futures market and has suggested that Northpoint hedge its second development. Minicucci admitted that he didn't fully understand the concept yet but listened intently as Loth riffed on the possibilities: What if you had a development with a $10 million projected profit? Is there some amount you would be willing to give up to ensure that the profit would be there in five years? 
 ''Does it become an expense line item?'' Minicucci chimed in, warming to the idea. ''Like any other kind of insurance?'' But then Loth interjected, briefly stifling the chatter, ''Or if you're so uncertain about the project that you have to hedge it, do you still go ahead and do it?'' If the market in housing futures causes builders to ask more of these questions, that may be the best outcome of all.

HEADLINE: MANHATTAN ON THE MOSKVA 

BYLINE: By Brett Forrest. 
Brett Forrest lives in Moscow and has written for Vanity Fair, Fortune and ESPN magazine.

 BODY:
Sergei Polonsky was short 900 tons of concrete, and he wasn't interested in excuses. It was a sweaty July morning at a construction site just outside central Moscow, and several contractors were arguing over whom to blame. The air-conditioned office overlooked hard-hatted workers scrambling through the dust several stories below, cranes swinging into position high above their heads.
A Russian real estate developer, Polonsky is building Moscow's first genuine modern skyscraper, the Federation Tower. When it reaches its full height, perhaps as early as next year, and at a cost of some $740 million, the tower will be the tallest building in Europe. It forms the centerpiece of Moscow City, a sprawling financial district that will inject a new modern character into this ancient, frenetic city.
 From across the meeting table, Polonsky focused on the deputy director of his company's concrete division, a middle-aged man with white hair and reading glasses that hung off the tip of his nose. The entire inner structure of the Federation Tower is composed of concrete, so the shortfall presented no small jam. ''You have three days to solve this problem,'' Polonsky told him, ''or you can submit your resignation.'' 
 Polonsky is 6-foot-6 and has a head of curly sandy hair that assumes various odd shapes depending on the humidity. His smooth rounded face makes him seem approachable. But in this notoriously tough town, no one achieves Polonsky's success by being everybody's best friend, least of all someone who is, like him, just 33. 
 Following the meeting with the contractors, Polonsky and Artur Aleksandrov, the project's perpetually hassled chief of construction, grabbed their hard hats and headed out for an inspection walk of the looming tower, already 50 stories high. The Federation Tower is not the only building making visible progress around Moscow City. Several office complexes rise into the air in various states of completion in what many Russians are calling the Moscow Manhattan. It is a sweeping space -- 250 riverside acres that will consist of 18 buildings and 43 million square feet of new real estate from 13 developers. At a projected cost of $10 billion to $12 billion, Moscow City is promoted by its developers as the largest investment and construction project in Europe. 
 The Federation Tower is the showpiece. It will actually be two towers, the taller one with 93 floors and a height of 1,161 feet, and the other with 63 floors. A 1,470-foot spire will rise between the monoliths, with glass elevators running up its core, offering a panoramic view and entry into the buildings. The towers will have 4.5 million square feet of high-end office space, luxury apartments, shops, restaurants and a 44-story Grand Hyatt hotel. The overall impression of the architect's rendering of these slightly bowed, glass-sheathed towers and central mast is that of a mammoth sailboat rising above the Moskva River. A blue banner hugging one side of the smaller tower reads, ''This is only the beginning.'' 
 As Russia regains its economic and political clout, Polonsky and other young developers are building architectural icons on an enormous scale, visible symbols of the nation's new wealth. The Russian state is now flush with cash. High prices for the country's largely renationalized natural resources -- oil, gas and metals, especially -- and President Vladimir V. Putin's efforts to tighten the screws on government agencies have given investors, foreign and domestic alike, reason to believe that the risk of doing business here has greatly diminished. Last year, Moscow real estate values soared, the Russian stock market grew by 90 percent and Standard & Poor's upgraded its rating on Russia (its evaluation of the viability of doing business in the country). Foreign investment in Moscow grew 67 percent in 2005 from the previous year, to $25 billion. And while there are many critics of the Kremlin's aggressive control of big business, Putin has created a measure of economic stability. And that is what investors want.
 City leaders first began discussing the Moscow City concept in the 1980's. The idea was to create a commercial district along the lines of La Defense in Paris or Lower Manhattan in New York. Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov and his deputies fixed on a site on the Moskva River embankment, two and a half miles from the Kremlin. There were 22 factories and warehouses at that location, along with several dilapidated apartment buildings, a typical Moscow hodgepodge. The city demolished the structures and began soliciting investment. Then came the country's economic crisis in the summer of 1998, which stalled development but didn't keep the mayor's office from campaigning for the new business district. ''We spent 10 years marketing Moscow City,'' says Iosif Ordzhonikidze, the deputy mayor for foreign affairs and economic relations. ''We were doing it when the stores had nothing in them.'' 
 Now Moscow is booming. It's the biggest city in Europe, with more than 10 million people, and as the cultural and financial capital of the Continent's eastern half, it is striving to live up to its status. Cranes twist across the skyline, great dust clouds billow from countless digs: roughly 80 million square feet of real estate will be built this year. But Moscow's transformation goes beyond the mere number of structures. It is the nature of these new developments that matters most, as modernization and image enhancement have become just as important to the civic leaders as the supply of basic services. 
 The Kremlin's towers and palaces and the gargantuan structures of Stalin's era have long symbolized Moscow, distinct emblems of czarist and Communist authority. The skyscrapers now going up, however, would fit into the urban plan of any Western capital. And in this way, the Moscow planners and developers are trying to prove to the rest of the world -- and to Russians themselves -- that this country can compete with anyone.
 One workday evening, Polonsky summoned a dozen of the top managers of Mirax, his company, to one of his residences, a 16th-floor penthouse in the Golden Keys high-rise. A medieval warrior, it seemed, had handled the furnishings. A couple of crossbows, nicked and well used, dangled from the ceiling beams. In one corner stood a dummy dressed in samurai armor. In the bedroom was a king-size mattress attached to motorized chains and capable of traveling 10 feet into the air. A boa constrictor, as swollen as a fire hose, was coiled in a terrarium, his split tongue testing the air. 
 Polonsky had invited his managers over to play Mafia, a parlor game of bluff and strategy. Once everyone was seated around a long wooden table, Polonsky and two others were secretly designated as a criminal enterprise that then went about eliminating the other players. Polonsky regards this exercise, involving blindfolds, accusations and deception, as a kind of instructive corporate bonding. Learning to think like a member of an organized crime syndicate, apparently, can have its advantages.
 Polonsky frequently plays Mafia into the early morning hours. But on this evening, he concluded the session well before midnight, with an admonition that suggested he had some insight into the insidiousness of both work and play. ''You must remember, it's just a game,'' he told his employees. ''You shouldn't remember, 'Oh, I played with this guy and he kicked me out.' It's just a game.'' 
 Having sent his managers home, Polonsky made his way out to the balcony where he lighted a cigarillo and looked out over Moscow's great spread. Polonsky himself is a transplant. He was raised in St. Petersburg, where his mother worked in a post office and his father was a professional student, collecting one degree after another. Polonsky entered the armed forces after high school, joining an airborne division and serving in the Caucasus, an experience that he says ''forged'' him. ''In the army there is no such thing as no,'' he offers as an explanation of what he gained from the experience. Regarding other aspects of his military career, he chose to say very little. 
 Polonsky returned to St. Petersburg in 1994 after leaving the army, and, with a friend, Artur Kirilenko, started a business finishing apartments in public and private buildings. When hard times struck and building owners ran into money trouble, they began paying Polonsky and Kirilenko in apartments instead of cash. The turning point for the partners came when they took possession of an entire building, not just individual apartments. The structure was unfinished, and when Polonsky and Kirilenko added a few floors and sold the building, they had unwittingly become builders. It was one small step to becoming developers. 
 The two friends were like many people who profited in the early post-Soviet days: businessmen who appeared out of nowhere, able to adapt in a time of upheaval, capitalizing on circumstance. The 1998 financial crisis that swept the country was devastating to most but proved a boon to Polonsky and Kirilenko. Their company paid for construction costs in rubles, then turned around and sold apartments and offices to those who had dollars. With the ruble in free fall, they profited in the lag time between construction and sale. Dollars in hand, Polonsky and Kirilenko had placed themselves on the right side of the inflation catastrophe, and they quickly became wealthy. 
 Polonsky set about enjoying himself, indulging his taste for vigorous activity: hunting, parasailing, bungee-jumping, snowboarding, skiing, mountain biking, snowmobiling, off-road racing, piloting aircraft, even driving tanks and firing A-K 47's into the sky. This was all a prelude to his ultimate adventure. Polonsky spent several months in Star City, the headquarters of Russia's space program, where he trained to become a space tourist, just the third ever. He arranged to pay $8 million, but, Polonsky says, when engineers designed his spacesuit, they determined that he was too tall -- that his legs, jammed against a control panel, were sure to break on landing. The space agency returned all but $500,000 of his money, which he says was well spent, the disappointment of rejection outweighed by the thrill of belonging to the program. ''If you go to Star City, it's impossible not to want to do it,'' he says. He notes, with some pride, that the cosmonauts who trained with him phoned him from the International Space Station with New Year's salutations. 
 During all of this time, Polonsky's company was growing into one of the largest developers in St. Petersburg, eventually building Petrovsky Fort, a 540,000-square-foot complex that became the standard for business centers in the former capital. Polonsky opened an office in Moscow in 2000, after graduating from St. Petersburg State University of Architecture and Civil Engineering. Two years later Mayor Luzkhov appointed him as an adviser. He was not yet 30. 
 Such a quick rise to prominence in a place where cozy government relations have been a prerequisite to getting anything done has led people to assume that Polonsky is just another beneficiary of the crony system. But he would have you believe his success stems purely from his ability and willingness to be held accountable, from being, in other words, a professional, where professionals can be hard to find. ''I arrived in Moscow six years ago and I knew nobody,'' he says. ''In my first three months here I had 200 meetings, and I was surprised how unprofessional people were. Builders thought they were economists and vice versa.'' 
 No matter what he says, however, Polonsky can't shake speculation of high-level associations and sweetheart deals. ''There are all sorts of legends,'' he says. ''I'm the illegitimate son of Valentina Matvienko,'' the governor of St. Petersburg. ''Or I studied in the same university as Putin.''
 Putin, who is also from St. Petersburg, has surrounded himself with advisers who, like Polonsky, are from his hometown. Over Polonsky's desk hangs a lovingly rendered painting of Putin, the president's arm lazing over the back of his chair, a teasing grin on his face. Dangling idly in Putin's right hand is a pen, with which he may or may not ink his approval. When Putin traveled to China in March, Polonsky went along with him. 
 But Putin also favors the talented and accomplished, and Polonsky has a gift for attracting investment, making it stick and seeing a project to completion. In 2000, Mirax started on the one-million-square-foot Corona apartment complex in western Moscow; the company is now building 42 million square feet in the city. Mirax has become an emblem not just of Moscow's rapid development, but also of how the style of building there is changing. ''Polonsky and the Federation Tower are like a brand for us,'' says Nikolai Koshman, president of the Association of the Builders of Russia.
 In 2003, Polonsky won the bidding to build a tower on a particular parcel of Moscow City. He welcomed the publicity that went along with it, as well as the attention generated by his bid to travel in space. He is a frequent topic of discussion in the local press, sometimes drawing notice with ill-advised public statements. During one press conference, Polonsky claimed that the Federation Tower was designed to be impervious to terrorist attack by airplane. ''Regardless of how many planes hit it,'' he said, ''it won't fall down.'' Several of the project's engineers looked on in shock, aware of no such design. Nor did it hurt Polonsky's public profile that he was at one time palling around with Anastasia Volochkova, a ballerina with the Bolshoi Ballet. Polonsky has since married Natalya Stepanova, the president of a construction consulting company. But he has not given up his relationship with the limelight. ''He can attract attention to himself,'' Koshman says. ''Other developers are more modest.''
 In Moscow, a professional can find it rough going, surrounded on all sides by insularity, ineptitude, corruption and the persistent after effects of a command economy. ''It's very difficult to find suppliers who will sell goods to you,'' says Zhao Xiangqian, an executive manager with the China State Construction and Engineering Company, which Mirax hired to build the concrete structure of the Federation Tower. ''And they always want to change something at the last minute.'' (Polonsky did eventually get his concrete, but construction was delayed for several days.) 
 For Polonsky, these details are the least of his worries. The main difficulty in building the Federation Tower is that such a building has never been attempted in Moscow. The complexity and height of this structure bring into sharp relief the inadequacies of the current system. For one thing, there is no comprehensive building code in Russia that dictates how the tower should be built. Moreover, Mirax has never attempted a structure on this scale. ''We have mass experience building 35-floor buildings,'' says Aleksandrov, the chief of construction. ''But 90 floors is a totally different task.'' As a precautionary measure, Aleksandrov says, Mirax chose to erect the smaller tower first, to ''test our technology.'' Europe's tallest building, it turns out, is also Europe's tallest training exercise. 
 The Federation Tower started out on a shaky financial footing as well. When Polonsky broke ground, he had no outside financing for the skyscrapers. In Manhattan, for example, it is customary to secure 80 percent or more of the financing on a building before construction begins. ''In Moscow, you won't find a single investor who will give you money without seeing the building,'' Aleksandrov says. ''Not everyone has the ability to build in Moscow. Moscow can be very capricious.'' Polonsky began the project with his and Mirax's own money -- how much he will not disclose. As progress on the Federation Tower has become visible, investment has poured in. The major share of financing has come from Vneshtorgbank, the country's second-largest bank, which has extended a $250 million line of credit. The Kremlin owns 99.9 percent of Vneshtorgbank, meaning that the Russian government serves as the Federation Tower's primary financial sponsor. 
 Since there is very limited skyscraper-construction expertise in Russia, Polonsky hired the Chinese contractors as well as Turner International, a firm based in New York. Turner and the Chinese firm have worked together on several high-profile tall buildings, and on the Federation Tower they are essentially acting as their own regulators, making decisions as they go along. 
 This is how things work in Russia, where laws are often variably applied and where the only real rule for getting things done -- at least on this scale -- is to have government support. ''Much of what you see here is because of Polonsky's relationship with the Kremlin and the city government,'' says Thomas J. McCool, Turner's European manager, who works out of an office on the Federation Tower site. ''It's very Russian.'' 
 The new Russia is, in some ways, not so different from the old. The Soviets tore down thousands of buildings in Moscow, replacing them with monuments to their own way of thinking. A similar situation revisits the city now, as government authorities do as they please, obliterating any number of historical structures in the pursuit of unfettered development. ''We have too much money in Moscow,'' says Marina Khrustaleva, an architectural historian who is the chairwoman of the Moscow Architecture Preservation Society. She says that the city is losing as many as 300 historical buildings a year. ''Some people say it is too late,'' she says, that ''Moscow is already lost.'' While Khrustaleva does not object to Moscow's overall modernization, she does view Polonsky's towers as one more example of the unchecked loss of the city's traditional character. ''It's so simple,'' she says of the structure. ''It has no idea. This is speculative architecture.'' 
 The architects of the Federation Tower, Sergei Tchoban and Peter Schweger, are known for building solid, respectable buildings in Germany, where they are based. ''They're not superstars, but they have a good reputation,'' says David Sarkisyan, the director of Moscow's Shchusev State Museum of Architecture. ''They're not trying to jump out of their trousers, as we like to say, but they do stylish things.'' The tower is their opportunity for a grand showcase.
 Polonsky, too, is chasing big aspirations with this building. He is hesitant to discuss his vision of Moscow's future, if indeed he has one. Talk is still cheap in Russia, if not in fact hazardous, and Polonsky won't engage in philosophical testimonials. Still, he is clearly after something more, as he could earn a more certain profit by continuing to build the 35-story apartment blocks that have made him wealthy. ''I have never had such a powerful, creative client,'' says Tchoban, who was born and educated in St. Petersburg. ''Ninety-nine-point-nine percent of clients don't like to create anything new.'' 
 Trying to do something new, and especially to be the first one to reach a new marketplace can rattle the nerves. You might arrive too soon, before the market is ready to receive you. Right now, Polonsky has only a few confirmed commercial tenants, including Grand Hyatt and Vneshtorgbank, for the Federation Tower. The narrow distribution of Russia's wealth, as well as the sheer volume of commercial and residential space now under construction, raises doubts about how much demand there will be for high-price real estate. And that is Polonsky's biggest gamble. He doesn't know yet if he has hit the moment exactly, or whether he has judged incorrectly, and whether the tower will be an empty monument, or a flourishing emblem of a thriving country. 
 Polonsky, relaxed on his balcony over-looking the city, said that he had difficulty imagining how it had all come to pass, how he had gone from outfitting interiors to building Russia's first world-class skyscraper. ''Your eyes are afraid of a job, but your hands do it,'' he said. ''The propulsive power is the lack of knowledge. If I had known how difficult it would be, I never would have opened my own office.'' 
 He stubbed out his cigarillo and walked inside, having tired of discussing business. Polonsky preferred to talk about the thrill of Star City, and he played a DVD montage of his cosmonaut training sessions to illustrate the point. An anti-gravity plane takes him for a whirl. A centrifuge whips around, pushing him through eight G's. He climbs into a spacesuit and tinkers on a capsule that was submerged in a large swimming pool. 
 Then there is a shot from the launching pad. A handful of military brass and aerospace engineers gather around, as three cosmonauts prepare for the journey to the International Space Station. The cosmonauts climb the stairs into their capsule, a dense early-morning mist hanging thick and lighted by dreamy yellow lamps. The video then cuts to a shot of the rocket punching into space. The rocket grows smaller and smaller as it reaches into pure black. Polonsky watched, unable to turn away.

HEADLINE: ALL THIS USELESS BEAUTY

BYLINE: By Randall Patterson. 
Randall Patterson, who lives in Asheville, N.C., has written for The New York Times Magazine, New York and Mother Jones.

 BODY:
The road to paradise is lined with real estate companies and grading contractors, and if you don't get stuck behind a cement truck, you can get there from Asheville, N.C., in about an hour and a half. Highway 64 twists and climbs through the Nantahala National Forest, the temperature dropping about five degrees with every thousand feet. By the time you reach the Highlands Plateau, and the town of Cashiers, summer is about 15 degrees cooler. Six rivers flow from here, with hundreds of waterfalls, and people come to this place from all over the South to spend their summers. Since Cashiers is located in the middle of 800,000 acres of protected national forest, there's limited space to put them. William McKee, a real estate broker, explained how a beautiful environment becomes an economic one -- ''simple supply and demand.'' 
Most of the old family estates, including his, have been converted into gated golf communities, but about two miles east of town, he said, there's a canyon that has been owned by the Jennings family for more than a hundred years. He spoke of it with longing: one of the few box canyons in the eastern United States, a green mountain rising along one side, and on the other, a wall of ''huge rock cliffs not unlike Yosemite.'' Between them lie hundreds of acres of woods and streams -- all this right off Highway 64. ''From a marketing perspective,'' McKee said, ''it's just obviously a one-of-a-kind jewel.''
 I turned into the driveway, came over the rise and looked out over a rolling valley and what appeared to be an ancient, untouched Shangri-La. McKee had not exaggerated the grandeur at all. Lonesome Valley -- that was the name -- was owned by three siblings, who spoke of the land as of themselves. Sally Eason, a tall, equine redhead, 54 years old now, says she still imagines herself as that kid who grew up among the wet pine needles, the sound of katydids, frogs and whippoorwills. ''Emotionally,'' she says, ''Lonesome Valley is my soul.''
 Binford Sievers -- shorter, younger, hobbling on a cane -- describes it as ''this God-given mystical place,'' this ''center of the universe.'' She says, ''I love it as much as I do my children.''
 And then there is Richard Jennings III -- Dickie, as he is known -- who is stout and gentle and concealed behind a moustache. The land speaks most eloquently for itself, he says, but probably means more to him than it does to ''those two.'' The problem was, it was also worth a lot on the open market. Lonesome Valley was like the farm animal they loved as a pet. It was time for the slaughter but they didn't want to kill it.
 Dickie and his sisters agreed that a subdivision was the way to go. Binford, especially, admired the difficulty of the task. ''It's easy to safeguard the land when you don't do anything with it,'' she says, ''when you just pass it down and say, 'Here you go.''' What Dickie was trying to do -- preserve Lonesome Valley while developing it -- was another feat altogether.
 Lonesome Valley was the last valley, the end of a vast kingdom. Before the Jenningses came to the Highlands Plateau, Dickie's father has been told, ''the woods were so dark you couldn't read in them.'' Dickie's great-grandfather, a Pittsburgh oilman, showed up around 1895 with a few industrialist friends, and they bought the land for next to nothing, brought in the railroad and began hauling out the timber. E.H. Jennings owned more than 30,000 acres at one point, but most was sold for development. Ten thousand he left for his son -- Richard the First, if you will -- and his siblings, who in turn logged the land and sold it until only 600 acres remained, the last, best 600, which fell into the hands of Richard the Second, who did not easily let them go.
 Pa is a white-haired, square-jawed old statue of a man now. His children describe him as a maverick, a pioneer, and he seems to like that. ''I was born into relative comfort,'' he explains. ''The world was waiting in the industrial sector for me, and I elected to go 180 degrees in the opposite direction. A lot of people thought I was crazy. I didn't care.'' He grew up in a posh suburb of Pittsburgh and might have raised his own children there if, as a boy, he had not ventured each summer into these woods. Richard the Second rode his horse, hunted and fished -- developed, he says, ''a romantic streak.'' Also, he saw lumber companies transform the forests into ''a barren desert, and I hated that because I loved to be in them.'' By the time he was of age, he had decided he didn't want ''a handout from the country club'' and ''damn well didn't want to go back to that atmosphere of soot and industry and boardrooms and bookkeeping.'' In 1947, he quit Yale and set off for the woods ''to do something different, that hadn't been done.'' 
 Frances, the daughter of a stockbroker, ran into him four years later, loitering at a Junior League party in Asheville. She noticed he was wearing a white dinner jacket in February; the man obviously ''doesn't give a damn what anyone thinks of him,'' she concluded. Deeply attracted, she soon married him.
 As details of their family history come out, it appears that life in Lonesome Valley was not such an idyll after all. When Richard the Second took his bride home, she found his pioneer dream in full swing. His castle was little more than a cabin, what Binford calls ''the plainest house on earth.'' Three children arrived within four years, and Pa quickly let them know where they were -- that he had not come to the woods to indulge himself or, in any way, them. Lonesome Valley, in fact, was about 180 degrees from that sort of thing.
 ''Daddy said basically that privileged children are wrought with difficulty their entire lives,'' Binford remembers. ''And his opinion was that if a person was handed life on a silver platter, they have no backbone or character or, in some cases, a raison d'etre. And people who work for a living and earn what they own have a joie de vivre.''
 The dream he developed, he says, was to work for a living and ''not ravage the forest as I do it and not louse up the beautiful streams.'' The valley is situated in a temperate rain forest, and because there was no developed land nearby, it could rain and rain without sullying the streams. Pa began farming trout and breeding mink -- ''just a total departure'' from Jenningses past, Dickie says. He clearly enjoyed it. All day he would be gone in the sperm shed, mixing and mingling to create new colors, coming home in the evening to share the freshly stripped skins with Frances.
 Frances once made the mistake of inviting friends to Lonesome Valley, but Richard the Second disapproved and referred her instead to his friends, ''the mountain people,'' whom he found so self-reliant and inventive -- with ''plenty of brains hidden beneath their outward surface.'' She found them difficult to meet, but never invited her own friends back. With skins to clean and children to raise, Frances settled into the work of a pioneer wife. The house was surrounded by deep woods with dense undergrowth, and she could see nothing beyond. In the woods was a garbage pit. ''That's as far as I ever walked,'' she says.
 Dickie generally discerned between his parents as ''the warm one'' and ''the gruff, short one.'' The children defined themselves according to birth order, Binford says, which ''means a lot in determining who you are.'' Sally, as eldest, was always the gang leader. Binford says that as youngest, she has been the follower, to which Sally adds that babies are also typically ''bratty and want their way.'' It is Binford, in any case, who remembers asking for a soda, at age 6, and hearing Pa say he couldn't waste the dime -- but she could work for it. And it's also Binford who recalls receiving in their Christmas stockings only nuts, with shells on -- ''the kind you had to work to get.''
 The three children fitted together like ''a perfect puzzle,'' Sally says, and never argued, ''except one time, I pushed Dickie into the heater because I wanted the first bath.'' She felt ''real bad about that'' and thinks he's probably still scarred. The sisters agree that Pa's lessons were toughest on Dickie. Binford explains that her brother suffered typical ''middle-child angst,'' which was compounded by the fact that ''he was also Richard the Third, so he had this burden.''
 Shoveling manure for 25 cents an hour, Binford learned well that she was not privileged. Dickie, though, received additional ''manly jobs'' that were ''more example-giving,'' Sally says. As the boy changed the oil in the tractor, hammered nails straight, Pa stood by telling Dickie not to mess it up, and when he messed it up, to do it again. Dickie often messed up and says he was generally known as lazy and careless, always in the bottom of his class. His stories about Lonesome Valley are mainly about being alone.
 Pa took them into the woods and taught them what they could and couldn't eat, which snakes were poisonous and which weren't. Sally says they ''were raised to think: Watch where you are. Just be aware of your environment and don't mess up something that was created for you.'' It was difficult, though, not to be aware that Pa had messed up the woods a little himself. He admits to bringing some Pittsburgh into the mountains. ''You have to cling to those concepts,'' Pa says, ''if you're going to stay in business.'' So he had worn out a bulldozer leveling the land to build his trout farm, and he had brought in an unnatural number of mink. They have the same glands as skunks, Binford explains, ''and we had 6,000 of them.'' The woods were clotted with mink stink. ''The stench was overwhelming.''
 The greatest problem with the woods, though, was the woods. The Jenningses could get no television reception, had no telephone. ''We didn't have anything,'' Sally says.''We had no stimuli of any kind.'' ''There was a loneliness here,'' Binford says, and everyone said so, except Dickie. Even Pa had to confess that the mountain people were not ideal companions, that they were suspicious of anything new, which was just about everything -- including blacks, Jews, Yankees and Frances. The mountain people suffered from isolation, and the Jenningses did, too, until the children began assuming the outward surface of mountain people. When Sally was 8, their grandmother visited from Pittsburgh and shrieked, as soon as Sally opened her mouth, ''Oh my God, my granddaughter's turning into a little redneck!''
 As Binford tells it, ''My parents realized we would be limited our whole lives if we grew up speaking like that.'' Sally was sent to school in Asheville. Dickie and Binford followed, and before long -- for the better schools, of course -- everyone was living in ''the city'' most of the time. 
 Pa kept commuting to Lonesome Valley. On his way, as though to prevent them from getting airs, he dropped the children off at their private schools, among the Cadillacs and Benzes, in his manure-encrusted farm truck. ''God Almighty,'' Dickie remembers, ''talk about humiliation.''
 Back on the farm, Pa refused to admit defeat, but the mink stink grew so intense and the gnats so thick that, just for airflow, he finally cleared the forest around the house for 20 acres.
 As for that house, it's hard to explain -- something to do with the boiler -- but around 1970, Binford says, ''It really sort of blew up.''
 The children were in their 20's when Pa announced that he was going to give them Lonesome Valley. Sally saw the gift as a rite of passage, believing the patriarch had recognized that his children had learned what he had to teach. Pa explains, though, that just the opposite was true.
 Sally at the time was struggling in the trout business. Binford had married the first boy she ever kissed and had gone wandering the country, teaching transcendental meditation. (''Damn near penniless'' was Pa's view of her situation.) And Dickie seemed the most hopeless of all; he had dropped out of college, was also working at the trout farm and had developed, he admits, an addiction to cocaine.
 ''None of them had any prospects of supporting themselves,'' Pa says now. ''None of them.''
 And he had not fared so well, either. Until this point, his experiment in self-reliance had held no real consequences, for he had gone into the woods with about $400,000 -- ''a hell of a lot of money back then,'' he says. But since the mink and the trout farms had never amounted to anything but rather had been kept afloat only by the inheritance, and since the inheritance was virtually gone, consequences now loomed. Pa had nothing to give but the land. He gave it to them in annual installments, so they wouldn't lose the land to estate taxes when he died and couldn't convert it to cash, he says, until they matured and ''got their heads together and knew what they wanted to do.''
 Thirty years passed; the land changed, and the children did, too. In clearing the trees, Pa had opened up a view of the forest, and everyone could see, from a distance, that Lonesome Valley was beautiful. Dickie, from the ashes of the pioneer cabin, helped to construct a finer home, and Binford, bringing classmates to Lonesome Valley, recalls being told how lucky she was to have a summer home. Sally remembers a school friend, looking out over the backyard, asking with awe, Where's your property line? And Sally announcing: ''This is it. We don't have one.''
 ''Out here alone,'' Binford explains, they had never compared their gifts with any friends. ''We just got busy cracking nuts.'' But leaving the valley, the siblings understood what they had and what they didn't, that the world was much larger than Lonesome Valley, but that nearly everyone lived in smaller spaces. They came to view the scene of so much labor as others saw it, and exactly as Pa had not wanted -- as a privilege.
 Everyone adapted the teachings of Pa to become who he or she was born to be. Having followed her father into trout farming, Sally helped determine, first, that Lonesome Valley didn't have enough water to expand the company, and second, that the company needed a more ''cosmopolitan'' image. She took over operations in Waynesville, a nearby town, and started packaging the fish in more elegant wrappers and selling trout caviar. For the first time in 50 years, the trout farm is in the black.
 Binford divorced the first boy she ever kissed, outgrew the T.M. lifestyle, married a doctor and settled in Dayton, Ohio. She found a friendliness in the city she never knew in the country and was pleased that her urban children ''have much more diversity in their lives.'' She then divorced the doctor and got laid off from her job, and now she wants to come home to her family. They always made her feel 12 years old, she says, and ''it's a wonderful thing to feel 12 when you're 50.''
 ''Binford is the one who ended up in a tough way,'' Dickie says. He knows at least that it wasn't him. The lesson Dickie finally learned from Pa is that ''if you are financially dependent on him, it is a bear.'' Dickie quit the $1.10-an-hour job that Pa gave him on the trout farm in the mid-1970's, and at the entrance to Lonesome Valley, he opened a building supply store. He did it just in time for the building boom and was soon able to pay off the note Pa had co-signed and get him ''out of my hair.'' ''And I have not looked back,'' he says. He owns five building supply stores now. Dickie's rich. 
 Just as Sally came to regard the land as her soul and Binford to love it as she did her children, the three siblings grew ''incredibly close,'' Binford says. Their childhood feelings had evolved, according to Sally, into ''a profound respect and love for each other.'' Then about eight years ago, Lonesome Valley became finally and completely theirs, and it was as if Pa had set a cake down among them and left the room. 
 The sisters say they intended to keep it in the family, never to sell or change it, but then others began loving Lonesome Valley, too, and the tax obligation rose to about $20,000 a year. At the same time, the sisters began weighing the privileges of owning Lonesome Valley against others that money could buy. Sally considered that she would be able to purchase trout machinery without borrowing; she also liked ''the idea of having a nest egg that will be there when trout isn't.'' Binford had more basic needs and a lust for travel. She knew her father thought that money ruined a person. ''I want it, though,'' she says, ''just to try it out.''
 Thus, ''tears have been shed -- oh yes!'' says Binford, but the sisters decided to sell.
 Then their telephones rang. It was their brother, Dickie. ''Listen,'' Binford remembers him saying, ''if I could buy you guys out, I'd like to.''
 Dickie has been the caretaker of Lonesome Valley for 20 years, paying the taxes from his own funds. He says his plan was to pass the land on to his children intact, as it had been given to him and his siblings. His offer was to have the land appraised and to buy his sisters out over time, but they never even got to the appraisal.
 Binford was shocked that Dickie had the means to make such an offer; ''None of us has ever had money,'' she says. Sally seems to have been startled by his audacity; middle children, in her belief, are usually subservient and reticent. Binford's first reaction was ''Yeah!'' but then she talked to her big sister, who explained that while Dickie has a ''heart as big as the planet,'' she thought he was hogging. Sally imagined her brother and his four children in beautiful, spacious homes at Lonesome Valley, and herself and her three children having only a small, spare home there. ''And maybe not even that,'' Sally says. ''Maybe Binford and I would just be out of the loop. I was in no way interested.''
 Binford saw what she meant. She says she and Sally asked themselves, if Dickie later sold Lonesome Valley for more than he paid them: ''Will we resent him? And the answer was, Yes, we will.''
 ''It sounds selfish,'' Binford says, ''like I don't want him to have more than me, but the answer is more, I wouldn't want there ever to be anything to come between us'' -- like her brother having a bigger slice of Lonesome Valley than she does.
 The sisters told him they were sorry, but they couldn't crown him king. They would rather sell Lonesome Valley to a stranger. ''Our bottom line has always been, avoid disputes,'' says Binford, so Dickie knew not to make a scene. He says he was just glad they felt close enough to be honest with him, and claims not to have had a problem until the offers began to arrive.
 ''The money was ridiculous,'' Dickie says. But he knew that he had his grandparents and great-grandparents ''looking down,'' and also that his parents were watching. According to their terms of ownership, Lonesome Valley could be disposed of only by unanimous consent. And Dickie couldn't convince himself, even after the last bid came in at $35 million, that other developers ''would create something our family would be particularly proud of.'' He told his sisters he couldn't sleep imagining Lonesome Valley being developed by a stranger. If it had to be done, he wanted to do it himself.
 The sisters understood. They couldn't grant Dickie the full privileges of a king, but if he wanted to do the work, that was as it should be. Binford explains that men are ''the responsible party,'' and that her brother probably does feel a greater need ''to do the right thing here,'' just being the man that he is. ''He's Richard the Third, and he's been given the responsibility of being the Richard to change Lonesome Valley,'' Binford says. ''It's a huge burden, a huge burden. It's up to him to carry on with dignity and honor.''
 Dickie had never developed anything before. His grandfather had loved money; his father, the land. He was the strange amalgam who would complain how ''these developers'' and ''this influx of new people'' had changed his town, even as he sold those developers the concrete.
 Returning to Lonesome Valley, he wanted, as his father had, to do things differently -- to make a lot of money without destroying the land. ''What we're trying to do,'' he says, ''is to create a community within this gorgeous setting and disrupt it as little as possible.'' He seemed almost to believe that he could install people in the woods without the creatures of the woods even noticing. Dickie was loath to disturb the animals, but as a developer, his chief responsibility was to people -- to transform the scene of his childhood into a comfortable place for people to live.
 The first step, begun about two years ago, was a vast wilderness beautification program. Binford had dreamed of this sort of thing for years. The valley had been rather untidy, and ''I've always thought we should clean the place up,'' she says -- get rid of the dead wood and just have it be ''more pristine and fields of grass.'' Pa began the program when he cleared the meadow. Now Dickie and his men imported hundreds of loads of fill dirt to create the meadow's rolling effect. For the green, they brought in sod. The view of the green rolling meadow has also been improved by trees that have been planted -- a willow, a dogwood, some apple trees -- to look as though they ''just grew there,'' Sally says. In other places, to open a window onto the view, trees that did just grow there have been removed.
 Dickie stands before this view of nature as he describes to visitors the added value. Already, gravel roads push through the trees to the farthest reaches of Lonesome Valley, and before they are paved, water, sewer and power lines will go coursing through them, with high-speed Internet and cable TV. Dickie's woods will be wired, and he will add all of the pleasures the Jennings children never enjoyed. There will be a pool that looks like a lake, sports fields that look like pastures, a ropes course on Cow Rock and a fitness center, says Dickie, positioned so that ''when you're in there on your treadmill, you've got the opportunity to stare at that view.''
 Cow Rock, Dickie explains, is ''the one that's got our logo on it'' -- an ancient mineral deposit in the form of a cow that has been appropriated as the corporate seal. Dickie's intent is to create in the wilderness ''a relaxed, laid-back atmosphere where when you drive in, you sort of throw away your watch and cellphone.'' Since he and his sisters were raised here together, he assumes that they share the same vision for Lonesome Valley, but everyone, it seems, looks from a different angle. Sally's desire is to have a five-star culinary establishment, serving a lot of trout. She says it's part of the plan; Dickie says it won't be that fancy. Binford dreams of a spa in Lonesome Valley, with a main building offering massages and salt and mud baths, and ''spa outposts'' with masseuses situated near the waterfalls. ''Doesn't it sound heavenly?'' she asks. The effect of spa treatment, she says, can be compared only to ''the deepest meditation,'' and the three of them have definitely seen the spa as a main attraction. But of the spa, Dickie says only that there will be ''a very small one.''
 All of Lonesome Valley's amenities will be tucked away inside old barns. Binford has imagined flattening the ''ugly mink farm buildings,'' the ''primitive shacks,'' but has come to accept her brother's preference for ''Southern Appalachian vernacular.'' If Lonesome Valley cannot remain purely a natural setting, Dickie explains, then it ought to look like an old farm and every house like an old farmhouse. He points for example to the rebuilt Jennings family home, which is now the clubhouse. Inside, the house is strictly deluxe, all granite countertops and stainless-steel appliances. The exterior, though -- with its tin roof ''pre-rusted so it looks old-timey,'' he says, and its salvaged barn siding painted a hue called Spanish Moss, ''a color we feel is acceptable here'' -- is a study in modesty. Binford understands that by constructing what looks like an old house, Dickie made it appear almost as if ''it sprung from the earth a long time ago.'' By allowing new construction of only old-timey buildings, and only on large, wooded lots, and not at all in the meadow or on the mountainsides, Dickie is trying to hide the evidence that Lonesome Valley has been developed at all. He knows that the woods -- and not the spa or the restaurant -- are still the main attraction for people and that their appearance, at least, must be preserved. Buildings ''must fit quietly into the existing landscape,'' the design guidelines decree. ''Shiny finishes are not allowed.''
 Arranging Lonesome Valley just so, Dickie intends to set it in amber with land conservancy grants, deed restrictions and architectural guidelines so that future generations will never be able to make the decisions about their lots that the Jenningses have made about their valley. Lonesome Valley becomes the master-planned nature community, and even better, as a canyon, the natural gated community. Dickie and his sisters do not say they are developing their land, but instead prefer to call it ''sharing our home.'' Binford explains that she doesn't feel the least bit guilty ''about giving people the opportunity to come into contact with God's nature.'' God may be, in fact, thanked for making them caretakers of Lonesome Valley, she says, ''because we want to share it.''
 They divided the valley into 210 lots, of which about a fifth have been taken. With land alone ranging, Dickie says, from $450,000 to more than $3 million, the new residents won't be Pa's mountain people, but rather more in line with great-grandpa's crowd. Dickie thinks of them, he says, as ''like-minded people,'' and Sally pictures them almost as those creatures of the forest -- retiring sorts slipping into camouflaged summer homes. Maybe the Jenningses will hardly notice them. Binford, though, hopes to embrace the new arrivals, for ''the more people there are,'' she says, ''the more heart there is, the more spirit, the more joy.'' In sharing their home, ''we're welcoming them into our family.'' And, she adds, ''by sharing it, we can still live there.'' 
 Here is the crux of the matter: While sharing their home is a generous act, Sally explains that it is also ''a way for everyone,'' and not just Dickie, ''to have a beautiful home.'' Binford, who hopes to realize $5 million from the deal, sees it additionally as a means to avoid working ''50 hours behind some desk.'' Except for Ma and Pa, who are safely nestled in their Asheville rest home, the whole family plans to live together again in Lonesome Valley, this time in comfort and leisure. And is this better than just letting Dickie own and preserve it? Let's be realistic here, Sally says. Dickie was going to do this anyway. ''Dickie not developing Lonesome Valley,'' she adds, ''would be a little like Einstein deciding not to share his theory of relativity. It's almost too much to hold in.''
 Dickie admits now that after he ''got through the emotional part'' of accepting that Lonesome Valley would have to be developed, he proceeded directly to another emotional part -- zeal for working in such a beautiful place. It should be a masterpiece, he says, ''the neatest development in western North Carolina.''
 Perhaps they'll profit less than they would have by just selling it, but Dickie figures they'll make enough. He expects to be reimbursed for all the taxes paid, and to benefit from the business his subdivision should bring to his building supply store at the entrance and from a nice deal he has worked with his sisters. Sally had complained that he was developing at a ''snail's pace''; Dickie bought a chunk of their shares, quieting them while entitling himself to half their proceeds. ''We're trying to do the right thing here,'' he says. ''The thing I've learned is that if you're doing the right thing, you'll probably make money.''
 At the end of June, the family gathered again at Lonesome Valley for the wedding of Sally's son Ben. The couple stood before the heirloom view, with clouds lingering above them from a storm the night before, and something of an ominous note, too, when they were joined for ''richer or poorer.''
 Afterward, the family portraits. ''Get real close to one another,'' the photographer said. ''A little closer, a little closer.. . .'' And Sally, as mother, stood proud and beaming, and Binford, behind the groom, could barely be seen, and Dickie was making jokes, and Pa was glowering at Dickie for not taking the task seriously.
 In the clubhouse later, Pa sank into one of Dickie's soft chairs and said he was pleased to have been able to give his children something of value. ''It's a compromise, is what it is,'' he said. You should never erase ''the original primeval quality'' of the forest, but also, when you have your family to support, he has learned, you can't cling to a dream about the land. ''I can't help it that one's been a moneymaker, one's been a survivor and one's been in trouble,'' Pa said. ''I can't help that.'' But with the development of Lonesome Valley, ''I'll leave the world thinking they all benefit from this land.'' Dickie will come out with the most, of course. ''But what the hell,'' he said. He's providing for his sisters. He deserves it.
 The boy is just ''superb,'' said Pa. ''He's taken hold in a way I never anticipated. It's almost unfathomable.''
