HEADLINE: The Three B's Are Back, And So Is the One R (Reich)

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH; Compiled with the assistance of Ben Sisario.

 BODY:

Dates are subject to change.

September

MUSICIANS FOR HARMONY Ordinarily a fifth anniversary would be something to cheer about, but this series, born in response to the events of 9/11, invites reflection, not celebration. The pianist Leon Fleisher, the violinist and composer Mark O'Connor, the Orion String Quartet and others present a fifth annual concert for peace. Monday. Merkin Concert Hall. musicians4harmony.org. 


MOZART'S REQUIEM If your needs for the 9/11 anniversary are more activist than contemplative, here is a chance to get involved musically, as Judith Clurman conducts a sing-in with the Juilliard Orchestra and Choral Union. It starts at 12:30 and is free, but tickets are required. Musical scores will be provided. The event is sponsored by the New York Mets, who have found any number of ways to make themselves lovable this season. (The team itself will be otherwise occupied, with the Marlins in Florida.) Monday. Carnegie Hall.

CANADIAN OPERA COMPANY This troupe wastes no time in putting its new house to the ultimate test, with three performances of Wagner's four-opera cycle, ''Der Ring des Nibelungen.'' The novelty here is that each opera has a different director. Three have already appeared; ''Das Rheingold,'' directed by Michael Levine, who also supplies the unifying set design, is new. Atom Agoyan directs ''Die Walkure''; Francois Girard, ''Siegfried''; Tim Albery, ''Gotterdammerung.'' Tuesday-Oct. 1. Four Seasons Center for the Performing Arts, Toronto, (416) 363-8231, ringcycle.ca.

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC In keeping with recent tradition, Lorin Maazel's gala opening concert will rock no party boats: just the ubiquitous Mozart (the Two-Piano Concerto, with Emanuel Ax and Yefim Bronfman) and Beethoven (the ''Egmont'' Overture and the ''Eroica'' Symphony). The first subscription concerts open with a touch of adventure: Hans Werner Henze's ''Sebastian im Traum,'' a Philharmonic co-commission with other orchestras. But the plaguing problem for new music at the Philharmonic: How many listeners will manage to arrive late, just in time for Itzhak Perlman's performance of Bruch's First Violin Concerto? Wednesday; Thursday-Saturday, Sept. 19. Avery Fisher Hall.

'SEMELE' Since Paul Kellogg became general director of the New York City Opera a decade ago, Handel has become the company's calling card. So it is appropriate that ''Semele'' is the first new production of the final season of Mr. Kellogg's distinguished tenure. Stephen Lawless is the director, and Elizabeth Futral and Vivica Genaux should provide plenty of vocal sparkle. (Further on the Handel front, ''Flavio'' returns on April 4 with the countertenor David Walker in the title role.) Opens Wednesday. New York State Theater.

NASHVILLE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA This newly energized ensemble presents its first subscription series in its new home, which just opened with a gala concert. The hall is named for Kenneth Schermerhorn, who was the orchestra's music director during a period of intense growth, from 1983 until his death last year: as proficient an orchestra builder in Nashville, evidently, as he had been at the Milwaukee Symphony through the 1970's. He was also a composer, and his ''Jubilee: A Tennessee Quilting Party for Orchestra'' opens the program, which will feature the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and be conducted by Andrew Litton. Thursday-Saturday. Schermerhorn Symphony Center, (615) 687-6400, nashvillesymphony.org.

PACIFIC SYMPHONY This solid but relatively unrecognized ensemble hopes to add to its stature with a new home, the Renee and Henry Segerstrom Concert Hall (not to be confused with the present Segerstrom Hall, named for the same donor), no matter that it lies more or less in the shadow of Disney Hall in Los Angeles. Carl St. Clair, the orchestra's music director, conducts the two opening concerts, each featuring a premiere: William Bolcom's ''Canciones de Lorca'' (sung by Placido Domingo) in the first and Philip Glass's ''Passion of Ramakrishna'' in the second. In addition Midori plays Beethoven's Violin Concerto on Saturday. Friday-Saturday. Orange County Performing Arts Center, Costa Mesa, Calif., (714) 556-2787, ocpac.org.

'THE PEONY PAVILION' Even abridged, Kenneth Pai's production of Tang Xianzu's 1598 opera runs some nine hours, and it holds great promise. Among other attractions, a press release says, Mr. Pai uses young stars, ''countering tradition that has older veteran performers in the leading roles.'' That's a good idea, as Chen Shi-Zheng showed in his presentation of this work in all its 19-hour glory at the Lincoln Center Festival in 1999 (which the release refers to merely as ''a previous production''). Mr. Pai's version with the Suzhou Kun Opera Theater of Jiangsu Province can only be welcomed, and we on the East Coast are left to lament that it is not coming here, at least not anytime soon. Friday-next Sunday, Zellerbach Hall, University of California, Berkeley, (510) 642-9988, calperfs.berkeley.edu. (The production moves on to the University of California, Irvine, Sept. 22-24; the University of California, Los Angeles, Sept. 29-Oct. 1; and the University of California, Santa Barbara, Oct. 6-8.)

SILK ROAD ENSEMBLE A must-hear for musical adventurers, and a must-see, if only as a rare opportunity to experience Zankel Hall in a different stage configuration. Before the hall opened, in 2003, a big selling point was that it would be able to change shape to suit various types of performances. Not so easily done, it turns out, and the only departure from the conventional stage setup so far has been a kind of surround audience seating for the culminating concerts of a Silk Road Project workshop two years ago. The same is promised for this second workshop. Yo-Yo Ma, the project's godfather, will again oversee the festivities with, you may be sure, his typical exuberance. Saturday-next Sunday.

'DAYS OF AWE' The 92nd Street Y's annual concert for the Jewish High Holy Days, ''Days of Awe: Who Shall Live and Who Shall Die,'' takes an ecumenical turn with performances by the choir of Trinity Church on Wall Street, conducted by Owen Burdick. The sensitive and thoughtful baritone Sanford Sylvan is the artistic director of the event, which combines performances of works by Josquin, Lassus and Arvo Part with readings and commentaries. Next Sunday.

JANINE JANSEN This young Dutch violinist has been called the Queen of the Downloads in some quarters, as much for her cheesecake image, one suspects, as for the quality of her recordings. She seems intent on challenging her German counterpart Anne-Sophie Mutter at her own glamorous game, but to judge from those recordings, Ms. Jansen, too, has the musical goods, and she has the respect of seasoned and serious musicians. Here she performs excerpts from Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' and Bach's E major Concerto and (joined by the lively Eriko Sato) Concerto for Two Violins with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra in the Great Hall to open the Metropolitan Museum's concert season. Sept. 18.

ST. LUKE'S CHAMBER ENSEMBLE This respected and versatile New York institution, which was quick to take its place among the lively attractions at the intimate Zankel Hall at Carnegie in recent years, now becomes a cornerstone in the programming of an even newer and more intimate auditorium, the Gilder Lehrman Hall of the Morgan Library, opened last May. When the three concerts originally scheduled sold out on subscription well before the start of the season, the Morgan added a series of repeat concerts, and those too sold out quickly. You can catch the same programs at the Brooklyn Museum, or you can cultivate a friendship with a generous ticketholder. The series kicks off with music of Vivaldi, Handel and Bach. Sept. 20, 23 (also Feb. 6, 8; April 24-25). Morgan Library and Museum.

CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER So begins the society's first season fully planned by its new artistic directors, the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han, and its last for now in Alice Tully Hall, soon to be renovated. On paper the opening program looks like a mishmash, with works by no fewer than 10 composers, ranging from Vivaldi to Nicholas Maw, Leon Kirchner and Bright Sheng. But it sounds themes to be developed later in the season, in series called ''Through Brahms: A Path From Schubert to Kirchner'' (Oct. 20-Nov. 7), ''Baroque Festival'' (Dec. 8-19), ''An English Musical Renaissance, 1900-30'' (Feb. 11-25) and ''Premiere Program'' (April 27-May 22), and in individual programs. The season, one trusts, will sort itself out in fascinating ways. The opening program still looks like a mishmash. Sept. 21. chambermusicsociety.org.

'SOPHIE'S CHOICE' Meryl Streep may seem to be everywhere at the moment, onstage as well as on film, singing as well (well, almost as well) as acting, but don't expect her to reprise the leading role she played in the 1982 film version of William Styron's novel in the American premiere of this opera by Nicholas Maw. Not that the production at the Washington National Opera will lack star power, with the mezzo-soprano Angelika Kirchschlager singing the title role. Marin Alsop conducts. Opens Sept. 21. Kennedy Center Opera House, (800) 876-7372, dc-opera.org.

MET OPEN HOUSE Huh? What ever happened to the secretive and exclusionary old Metropolitan Opera? Peter Gelb arrives as general manager firing from both barrels, and here, even before the season starts, he is throwing the doors open to the public. Visitors (or at least a houseful of them) can acquire free tickets to the dress rehearsal of the season-opening ''Madama Butterfly,'' observe set changes, attend panel discussions and walk across the stage (probably not during the rehearsal). Sept. 22. Metropolitan Opera House.

'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' As planned by Joseph Volpe, Peter Gelb's predecessor as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, the season was to begin in typical fashion with a gala presentation of opera excerpts. Mr. Gelb decided instead to kick things off in dead earnest, with a new production of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' directed by Anthony Minghella (of film fame) and picked up from the English National Opera, where it created something of a sensation last season. Cristina Gallardo-Domas, acclaimed for her interpretation of Butterfly, takes the role here, and Marcello Giordani is Pinkerton. The production treats the work as a Japanese play and, among other innovations, uses bunraku-style puppets. The ever restless Mr. Gelb has done other tinkering with Mr. Volpe's season as well. Opens Sept. 25.

NORTON LECTURES With his amassing of high-profile positions around the world (most recently at La Scala in Milan), Daniel Barenboim brings to mind Herbert von Karajan when he was widely called Generalmusikdirektor of Europe. But in delivering the Charles Eliot Norton Lectures at Harvard, Mr. Barenboim calls to mind Leonard Bernstein, whose lectures ''The Unanswered Question'' of 1973 are the association most music lovers have with the annual series. Mr. Barenboim's six talks are titled ''Sound and Thought'' (though can politics be far behind?). And about those Bernstein associations? Don't discount Mr. Barenboim's chances of becoming the next music director of the New York Philharmonic, should he want such a thing. Sept. 25-29, Oct. 3. Sanders Theater, Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass., (617) 495-2791, music.fas.harvard.edu.

VLADIMIR FELTSMAN When Mr. Feltsman arrived from the Soviet Union in 1987 to great expectations, he told skeptical reporters that he was not an old-school Russian pianist eager to flex his muscles, that he was as much interested in music of the Classical era as in the big Romantic war horses. And here, perhaps, is the ultimate demonstration: five evenings covering all the Mozart piano sonatas and other keyboard works, played on a fortepiano. Sept. 28, Oct. 12, New School, 66 West 12th Street. Sept. 30; Oct. 3, 10, Mannes College, 150 West 85th Street, (212) 496-8524, mannes.newschool.edu.

BALTIMORE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Yuri Temirkanov bade the orchestra farewell as music director in June. But now -- as the orchestra awaits the installation of his successor, Marin Alsop, next year -- Mr. Temirkanov is back to open its new season, something he did not always manage even when he was acting as music director, because of his competing commitments at the St. Petersburg Philharmonic in Russia. Here he observes the Shostakovich centenary with a minifestival, demonstrating his mastery of that composer's music with the Symphony No. 5 in the first week and No. 10 in the second. Sept. 29-Oct. 1; Oct. 5-7. Meyerhoff Symphony Hall, Baltimore; Music Center at Strathmore (Sept. 28), North Bethesda, Md.; (410) 783-8000, baltimoresymphony.org.

SILK ROAD CHICAGO After its Carnegie Hall workshop and Zankel concerts, the Silk Road Project returns to its yearlong residency in Chicago. The Chicago Symphony Orchestra, in its opening-night gala, features Yo-Yo Ma, the project's spearhead, in Dvorak's Cello Concerto. But more to the point, it performs ''Night Music: Voices in the Leaves,'' by the Uzbek composer Dmitri Yanov-Yanovsky, and vaguely Oriental works by Rossini (''Italian Girl in Algiers'' Overture) and Stravinsky (''Song of the Nightingale''). Miguel Harth-Bedoya conducts. Silk Road Chicago continues through June. Sept. 30. Symphony Center, (800) 223-7114, cso.org.

October

STEVE REICH @ 70 One of the most encouraging developments in New York concert life in recent years has been the collaborative spirit that has arisen among presenting institutions. Here the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center join to celebrate the 70th birthday of the innovative and influential composer Steve Reich. The academy offers dance in the opera house (Oct. 3, 5-7). Carnegie has a professional training workshop and young artists concert in Zankel Hall (Oct. 13-19); concerts with Steve Reich and Musicians in the Stern Auditorium and Zankel Hall (Oct. 21-22); and an afternoon of discussion and performance in Weill Recital Hall (Oct. 22). Lincoln Center presents a concert by the Los Angeles Master Chorale in Alice Tully Hall (Oct. 28) and performances of ''The Cage'' at John Jay College, 899 10th Avenue, at 59th Street, Manhattan (Nov. 2-4).

CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA If the verdict is still out on Franz Welser-Most in his fifth season as music director of the orchestra -- as, in some quarters, it seems to be -- this high-profile engagement, opening Carnegie Hall's season, should tell some tales. The pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, playing Mozart, and the bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff, singing Mozart and Mahler, are high-powered guest artists. The modern (''Un Sourire'' by Messiaen) mingles with the freshly minted (''Touche'' by Hanspeter Kyburz). The Johann Strauss overture and waltzes in the first program should be delicious, and Bruckner's Fifth Symphony in the last could be revelatory. As for Carnegie, although this is the first season in which Clive Gillinson has had substantial input as executive and artistic director, no changes of direction are yet apparent. Oct. 4-5, 7.

'L'ENFANT ET LES SORTILEGES' Ravel's charming little opera, performed in concert by Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic, should be a delight. But Saint-Saens's mighty ''Organ'' Symphony, which fills out the program, will -- with some dreadful-sounding electronic instrument -- inevitably serve as a reminder of the desperate need for a pipe organ in Avery Fisher Hall. With wonderful new or restored organs at Symphony Hall in Boston, Severance Hall in Cleveland, Disney Hall in Los Angeles, the Kimmel Center in Philadelphia and even the Overture Center in Madison, Wis., is it too much to hope that plans for the reconstruction of Avery Fisher will include the pipe organ that Kurt Masur always lusted after and helped raise money for? Oct. 5-6.

MARYINSKY FESTIVAL Are Valery Gergiev and the forces of the Maryinsky Theater spreading themselves too thin, with extended visits this season to Orange County, Calif.; Lincoln Center; and the Kennedy Center in Washington? They seem to be spending as much time in the West these days as at their home in St. Petersburg, Russia. A trip to London this summer met with mixed critical reactions, and the advance word on the Kirov Opera's Wagner ''Ring'' cycle, which is the opener and main attraction here (Oct. 7-11) on its way to the Lincoln Center Festival next summer, is iffy. In addition the Kirov Opera presents ''Boris Godunov,'' the Kirov Ballet offers ''Romeo and Juliet'' and ''Swan Lake,'' and the Kirov Orchestra performs two concerts in the new Segerstrom Concert Hall. Oct. 6-22. Orange County Performing Arts Center, Costa Mesa, Calif., (714) 556-2787, ocpac.org.

LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Roll over, Mozart, and tell Chuck Berry the news. Although the Mozart year remains very much in play, this season amounts to a Beethoven festival. (Like every other, some would say, but this one more than most.) For openers Bernard Haitink and the London Symphony bring their recently recorded survey of the nine symphonies to life. And life is the operative word, to judge from the vitality and the quick tempos on some of those recordings. Elder statesman though Mr. Haitink may be, his approach to these overfamiliar masterpieces remains fresh and energetic. Oct. 7-8, 10-11, 13. Avery Fisher Hall.

'L'ELISIR D'AMORE' Wasn't it just two years ago, when he was directing Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale'' at the Royal Opera in London, that Jonathan Miller was making noises about quitting opera altogether? It would have been a shame for the field to lose his teeming and irreverent imagination, but not to worry: he directed Janacek's ''Jenufa'' at Glimmerglass this summer, and here he is, directing another Donizetti work at the New York City Opera. The production, originally created for the Royal Swedish Opera in Stockholm and set in the American Southwest of the 1950's, promises soda jerks, Ford Fairlanes and pompadours. Opens Oct. 7. New York State Theater.

EARLY MUSIC AMERICA A highlight of the first New York Early Music Celebration in 2004 was the final round of this organization's medieval and Renaissance competition for North American artists. The return of the celebration, promised for this fall, has been put off at least a year, but here is another installment of the competition, featuring three groups from Canada and two from the United States. Incidentally, what ever happened to Asteria, the vocal duo that won in a walk two years ago? Those two would light up any season. Oct. 11. Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights, (888) 722-5288, earlymusic.org.

BEN HEPPNER The burly baritone Thomas Hampson tested the walls and rafters of the intimate new Gilder Lehrman Hall at its opening in May, and the auditorium seems destined, improbably, to become a home for big voices. Here the leading Wagner tenor of the day lets loose (alongside Wendy Bryn Harmer, a soprano), to open a series sponsored by the George London Foundation, which includes the soprano Andrea Gruber and others. Oct. 12 (also Jan. 14, March 18). Morgan Library and Museum.

'MOZART AT 250' Such, at least, is the working title of an exhibition of Mozart manuscripts, letters and first editions at the Morgan Library, which is otherwise doing such fine service to classical music this season with its new concert hall. The exhibition culminates in a rare first edition of the Requiem. Oct. 13-Jan. 7. Morgan Library and Museum.

GLIMMERGLASS OPERA This summer operation gives a precis of its coming season with excerpts from works based on the Orpheus legend by Monteverdi, Gluck, Offenbach and others. Oct. 13. Morgan Library and Museum.

BALTIMORE OPERA The songbirds of the New York City Opera's ''Semele'' migrate south for a production of Rossini's ''Assedio di Corinto'' (''The Siege of Corinth''). Elizabeth Futral sings the high-flying Pamira; Vivica Genaux, Neocle. Steven White will conduct, and Elizabeth Bachman will direct. Opens Oct. 14. Lyric Opera House, (410) 727-6000, baltimoreopera.com.

PIETER WISPELWEY Great Performers at Lincoln Center moves from the grand Beethoven of the symphonies to the intimate Beethoven of the works for cello and piano. But intimate as they are, they are not small in number or length. This excellent cellist is joined by the pianist Dejan Lazic in a journey lasting three hours (with two intermissions). Oct. 15. Alice Tully Hall.

CAPPELLA ANDREA BARCA That would be Italian for Andras Schiff. Mr. Schiff, pianist and fledgling conductor, and his hand-picked ensemble pick up where they left off last season, with Mozart: the Concertos Nos. 22-25 and the ''Linz'' and ''Jupiter'' Symphonies. Oct. 18-19. Alice Tully Hall.

ANNE-MARIE McDERMOTT Taking its cue from the success of its late-night concerts in recent Mostly Mozart festivals, Great Performers at Lincoln Center is introducing them into the regular season. Here, at 10:30, Ms. McDermott, a pianist, plays Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. The pianists Jeremy Denk and Sergey Schepkin follow with Bach recitals of their own. Oct. 19 (also Oct. 20-21). Kaplan Penthouse, 165 West 54th Street, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org.

'ALEXANDER NEVSKY' Better late than never (though that seems a paltry goal for an orchestra that aspires to leadership in the field, or should come by it naturally). Here, at long last, the New York Philharmonic catches up with a show that has been circulating for some two decades, a presentation of Eisenstein's classic 1938 film with Prokofiev's score performed live. The orchestra's dynamic young associate conductor, Xian Zhang, takes up the tricky challenge of pulling it all together. Oct. 19-21. Avery Fisher Hall.

NEW JERSEY SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA To open the orchestra's season and its season-long survey of the Beethoven symphonies, Neeme Jarvi conducts the First and the Ninth. Oct. 20, 22, 24. Halls in Newark and New Brunswick, (800) 255-3476, njsymphony.org.

'COSI FAN TUTTE' Pamela Armstrong and James Maddalena join other singers in a new production by Tim Albery at the New York City Opera (imported from the Glimmerglass Opera). But the biggest news is in the pit, with the return of Julius Rudel to the City Opera podium after a 25-year absence. Mr. Rudel, one of the company's founders, directed City Opera from 1957 to 1979. Opens Oct. 21. New York State Theater.

'SALOME' There is considerably less of Deborah Voigt to see since her gastric bypass surgery two years ago, but to judge from the vampy photograph in a season brochure for the Lyric Opera, Chicago operagoers will see much of what remains in her stage debut in the title role of Strauss's ''Salome.'' The new production, by Francesca Zambello, also features Kim Begley and Alan Held. Andrew Davis is to conduct, barring complications from his arterial surgery last month. Opens Oct. 21. Civic Opera House, (312) 332-2244, lyricopera.org.

KIROV ORCHESTRA Valery Gergiev's four concerts of Shostakovich symphonies with the Kirov Orchestra and the Rotterdam Philharmonic last season as part of the Great Performers series at Lincoln Center left audiences hungry for more, and here it is: Nos. 6, 8 and 11 to 14, completing the cycle. Oct. 23-24, 29. Avery Fisher Hall.

NHK SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA This may well be the world's most famous orchestra you've never heard. Though it is widely known by reputation and by recordings, its visits from Tokyo have been infrequent. (It appeared last at Carnegie in 1999; before that, in 1969.) And this appearance is all too brief: a lone concert of works by Takemitsu, Bartok and Ravel, conducted by the orchestra's music director, Vladimir Ashkenazy. Oct 23. Carnegie Hall.

IVO POGORELICH The first question is: Will he show up? Like his early supporter Martha Argerich, this Croatian pianist is given to cancellations, and he recently dropped all of his European appearances this year except for the American tour, citing his health. We are assured that he will appear here. Thus the second question: How weird will it be? Mr. Pogorelich, while endlessly gifted, has often put his gifts to eccentric if not perverse uses. If it comes off, this recital of Chopin and Schumann is sure to be one of the most scrutinized and talked-about events of the season. Oct. 26. Metropolitan Museum.

TOKYO STRING QUARTET With the blockbuster anniversaries of Mozart and Shostakovich this year, it has been hard to focus on lesser ones. But it is also the 150th anniversary of Schumann's death, as this group points out, stealing a march on the Schumann bicentenary in 2010. Here are three concerts of Schumann chamber, vocal and piano works, culminating in May with the great Piano Quintet. Alexander Lonquich is the pianist there; Alon Goldstein is the pianist in the first concert. Oct. 28 (also Jan. 20, May 12). 92nd Street Y.

RENE JACOBS This conductor's record label, Harmonia Mundi France, celebrates him throughout the season, as well it might. He has made a number of the most acclaimed recordings of early music over the last decade and more, and his series of Mozart operas has been a particular success. (''La Clemenza di Tito'' is just appearing.) Here is a new version of Handel's ''Messiah'' sure to be unconventional, by new as well as old standards, with the Choir of Clare College, Cambridge, and the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra. His recording of ''La Calisto,'' by Cavalli, will be reissued alongside the release of a new DVD of the production. October. (Other releases follow, including a DVD of a production of Monteverdi's ''Orfeo.'')

STING What is a rock star doing on the cover of the journal Early Music America? Performing music of John Dowland on a new album, ''Songs From the Labyrinth,'' with the lutenist Edin Karamazov. It's touching, in a way, that he wants to come to terms with this plaintive and refined music. It remains to be seen whether he should. October. Deutsche Grammophon.

November

GIDON KREMER Or should it be Krystian Zimerman? It is hard to know which of these supremely gifted artists to give top billing. Mr. Zimerman, who recently showed again what a superb Brahms pianist he is in a Deutsche Grammophon recording of the First Concerto with Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic, joins the incisive Mr. Kremer on equal terms in performances of the three Brahms violin sonatas. Nov. 1. Carnegie Hall.

EARLY MUSIC IN GILDER LEHRMAN HALL Lovers of early music have to hope that the intimate and inviting new hall in the Morgan Library will give the antiquarian scene in New York the shot in the arm it always seems to need. Here, at least, is a modest start: the Flanders Recorder Quartet, in the first of three concerts presented in collaboration with the Boston Early Music Festival. Nov. 1 (also, Kristian Bezuidenhout, fortepianist, Jan. 25; Paul O'Dette and Ellen Hargis, May 15).

'NEW MUSIC IN THE ROSE' In this series the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center gives more concentrated treatment to contemporary music, otherwise spotted throughout its season: here, works by Avner Dorman, Stuart S. Smith, Kevin Puts and Huang Ruo. Nov. 2 (also Feb. 1, May 10). Rose Rehearsal Studio, 165 West 65th Street, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org.

MUSICA ANTIQUA KOLN Any early-music group with a name referring to the city of Cologne (in whatever language) is a good bet. But here is the group that more or less set the standard, directed by Reinhard Goebel in a program of mostly German Baroque repertory, including music of several Bachs. Nov. 2. Zankel Hall.

MSTISLAV ROSTROPOVICH The former music director of the National Symphony Orchestra returns to conduct music by his friend Dmitri Shostakovich: the Symphonies No. 10 the first week and No. 8 the second. The surrounding concertos in this little festival are variously populated by the violinist Maxim Vengerov, the pianist Martha Argerich and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma. Nov. 2-4, 9-11. Kennedy Center, Washington, (800) 444-1324, kennedy-center.org.

BAVARIAN RADIO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Mariss Jansons visited Carnegie Hall last season with one of the two great European orchestras he directs, the Royal Concertgebouw of Amsterdam. Here he brings the other one, from Munich, with top-tier soloists: the soprano Karita Mattila in Strauss's ''Four Last Songs'' (an obvious choice), the violinist Gidon Kremer in Bartok's First Concerto (ditto) and the pianist Lang Lang in Beethoven's First Concerto (not at all an obvious choice for him). Nov. 3-5.

ZUKERMAN CHAMBER PLAYERS This group made news indirectly last season, when Pinchas Zukerman, the music director of the National Arts Center Orchestra in Ottawa, and his wife, Amanda Forsyth, its principal cellist, took abrupt leave and diverted their attention to chamber concerts. Having apparently made peace with the orchestra musicians in the meantime, Mr. Zukerman and Ms. Forsyth form the backbone of the players here in three programs devoted largely to Mozart. F. Murray Abraham is part of the first, delivering Salieri's great soliloquy from Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus''; he is perhaps more to be trusted in that role than when he hammed up a narration of Mozart's ''Thamos'' with the Brooklyn Philharmonic last season. Nov. 5 (also Dec. 17, March 25). 92nd Street Y.

HELENE GRIMAUD This fine pianist, especially strong in the Romantic repertory, makes her Carnegie Hall recital debut, playing Bach, Chopin, Brahms and Rachmaninoff. It shapes up as a big autumn for her, with the publication of her memoir in English translation, ''Wild Harmonies: A Life of Music and Wolves'' (yes, those would be her pet wolves), by Riverhead Books and the release of a new album, ''Reflections'' (with music of Robert and Clara Schumann and Brahms), by Deutsche Grammophon. Nov. 8.

'IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA' Remarkably, it has been a quarter of a century since the Metropolitan Opera mounted a new production of Rossini's perennial favorite. And this one, by Bartlett Sher (who directed ''The Light in the Piazza'' on Broadway), promises to be new indeed, somehow carrying the action into the audience. The Met audience? (These reality checks may be required for years to come.) One reason for the delay, undoubtedly, is that great Rossini singers have not exactly abounded. Here is one of the best in the title role, Juan Diego Florez. Opens Nov. 10.

ANNE-SOPHIE MUTTER Ms. Mutter and the pianist Lambert Orkis do for Mozart what they did so well for Beethoven in 1998, playing all the violin sonatas at Carnegie Hall. The problem is, Mozart wrote more of them, and the quality is not as uniformly high. Nov. 15, 17, 19. (The artists' recording of the works is to be released on Tuesday by Deutsche Grammophon.)

TRIO MEDIAEVAL The characteristic sound of these charming and gifted women is that of two sopranos soaring over a stable, velvety mezzo: as remarkable in its diversity as, when appropriate, in its unanimity, and always tightly knitted. The group, based in Oslo, plies two of its specialties here, medieval music and Norwegian songs, in what promises to be a delectable outing in the highly regarded series Music Before 1800. Nov. 19. Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 666-9266, mb1800.org. (The trio also appears at Merkin Concert Hall on March 28 in a program featuring music by Donnacha Dennehy.)

LONDON PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA Here's wishing Kurt Masur, now 79, the best of health and a fond return to New York. As this orchestra's principal conductor, he missed its American tour in the spring because of illness, and he recently canceled performances in Europe as well on his doctor's advice. These programs, including Brahms's Second Symphony and Beethoven's Third, will not surprise any who followed Mr. Masur's work at the New York Philharmonic from 1991 to 2002, but they promise much, with Elisabeth Leonskaja as soloist in Prokofiev's Second Piano Concerto and Sarah Chang in Sibelius's Violin Concerto. Nov. 27-28. Carnegie Hall.

'DON CARLO' Verdi's dark drama returns to the Metropolitan Opera with a starry array of singers. Nov. 30. [Article, Page 76.]

 December

HOUSTON GRAND OPERA Basil Twist and his puppets take over the house for Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel,'' and all the talk is of the Witch, standing 12 feet tall and to be sung by a tenor, John Easterlin, doubling as puppeteer. Opens Dec. 1. Wortham Theater Center, (800) 626-7372, houstongrandopera.org.

ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA A ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 7? Or No. 1a? In a program of Bachiana, Orpheus presents Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concertos Nos. 1 and 2, along with a new work by Stephen Hartke inspired by the First and using its instrumentation. It was not yet titled at press time; you see the problem. In addition, the pianist Jeremy Denk will perform Bach's Keyboard Concerto in D minor (BWV 1052). Dec. 2. Carnegie Hall.

NEW YORK COLLEGIUM In its ninth season, the collegium presents its first performance of Handel's ''Messiah.'' Don't expect a Victorian-scale inflation of forces from its fastidious English music director Andrew Parrott, but neither should there be any ideological tinge, like that stemming from Mr. Parrott's theories about the size (or lack of it) of Bach's choruses. More to the point, you have to hope that the group is in its best musical form, which was not the case at the end of last season. Dec. 6, 8. Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, (212) 717-9246, nycollegium.org.

ANONYMOUS 4 In what may be one of the hottest tickets of the season, this superb female vocal quartet, which disbanded in 2004 after 18 years of splendid service to medieval repertory, reunites to further its work in rustic Americana, begun belatedly with the hit album ''American Angels,'' also in 2004. Here the singers are joined by the folksy instrumentalists Darol Anger and Scott Nygaard. For those who can't beg, borrow or steal their way into the small hall, the brunt of this program will already have appeared on the quartet's CD ''Gloryland,'' from Harmonia Mundi France. Dec. 7. Merkin Concert Hall.

AMSTERDAM BAROQUE ORCHESTRA When the Baroque specialist Ton Koopman collaborated with Carnegie Hall in a choral workshop last season, they had a hard time finding enough aspiring period instrumentalists of sufficient quality to produce really professional performances. No such problem here, as Mr. Koopman brings his own forces, first in a program of Christmas music by Buxtehude, Corelli and Bach with the Amsterdam Baroque Choir in the Stern Auditorium at Carnegie, then in Bach's ''Musical Offering'' and ''Coffee'' Cantata in the closer confines of Zankel Hall. Dec. 7, 12.

ORCHESTRA OF THE AGE OF ENLIGHTENMENT In a program devoted to Bach and his heirs, Britain's elite period-instrument band seizes a last opportunity to salute Mozart in his anniversary year, and the tribute goes right to the heart with the sublime Serenade for 13 Winds (''Gran Partita''). Dec. 8. Miller Theater.

CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Pierre Boulez conducts, opening with Mahler's Seventh Symphony and ending with Bartok's ''Miraculous Mandarin.'' In a ''discovery'' program on the night between the full concerts, Mr. Boulez will put the Bartok on the dissecting table and analyze it before leading a performance of it. As another prime attraction, Pierre-Laurent Aimard plays Gyorgy Ligeti's Piano Concerto in the final concert, part of his Perspectives series. Dec. 8-10. Carnegie Hall.

'DON JUAN IN PRAGUE' Leave it to the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy to have the last word (more or less) on the Mozart year. The multifaceted avant-gardiste Iva Bittova sings Donna Elvira, evidently the lead character in David Chambers's ''recontextualized'' version of ''Don Giovanni,'' advertised as a digital media extravaganza. For all of that, the production is said to remain ''true to Mozart's music.'' (Tell it to Matthew Suttor, who is credited for musical arrangement and digital composition.) Dec. 13-16. BAM Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org.

KAIJA SAARIAHO Her ''Adriana Songs'' are performed with works by Debussy and Sibelius. The mezzo-soprano Patricia Bardon joins David Robertson and the New York Philharmonic. Dec. 14-16. Avery Fisher Hall. [Article, Page 78.]

ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S This versatile group does its various jobs so well and faithfully that it tends to be taken for granted. It shouldn't be. It opens its all-too-brief Carnegie Hall series with an intriguing program centering on British music, conducted by Donald Runnicles. Arvo Part's ''Cantus in Memoriam Benjamin Britten'' leads into Britten's Violin Concerto, with Midori as soloist, and the famous Purcell Chaconne in G minor introduces Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations. Dec. 14 (also Feb. 15, March 15).

WEST-EASTERN DIVAN ORCHESTRA As conductor, pianist, lecturer and would-be diplomat (or is it provocateur?), Daniel Barenboim is everywhere this season. Here he conducts his orchestra made up mostly of gifted young Arabs and Israelis. The night before, they perform at the United Nations in honor of Kofi Annan on his departure as secretary general. Dec. 19. Carnegie Hall.

'THE FIRST EMPEROR' Tan Dun's new work appears at the Metropolitan Opera. Opens Dec. 21. [Article, Page 73.]

'THE MAGIC FLUTE' Julie Taymor's circuslike production of Mozart's ''Zauberflote'' at the Metropolitan Opera in 2004 was more a popular than a critical success. The Met is banking on that popularity with this abridged version in English, presented on afternoons during the holiday season at ''family-friendly'' prices (all things being relative). The full German version, which opens on Oct. 7, will be running at the same time: twice, in fact, on the same day. (Stage changes, after all, are expensive.) Dec. 29-31, Jan. 1-2, 4.

January

MARIN ALSOP This is the first of several weeks of Baltimore Symphony concerts that Ms. Alsop will conduct before taking over as music director next season. Her community spirit is already in place: this program celebrates the 100th anniversary of the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, and Peabody students join the orchestra in performances of Strauss's ''Alpine Symphony'' and Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring.'' Jan. 11-14. Meyerhoff Symphony Hall, Baltimore; Music Center at Strathmore (Jan. 13), North Bethesda, Md.; (410) 783-8000, baltimoresymphony.org.

'RUSSIAN ROMANTICS' The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra presents its annual winter festival, this one right up the alley of its music director, Neeme Jarvi (unlike the Mozart festival last season, which he mostly sat out). He presents programs centering on Rachmaninoff, Tchaikovsky and the Mighty Five (a k a the Mighty Handful: Balakirev, Borodin, Cui, Mussorgsky and Rimsky-Korsakov). Jan. 12-28. Halls in Newark, Trenton, Red Bank and New Brunswick, (800) 255-3476, njsymphony.org.

'ST. MATTHEW PASSION' Carnegie Hall's annual choral workshop split into two segments last year: one Baroque, one contemporary. Here it reverts to form with an intensive study of a single masterpiece capped by a public concert. The Bach specialist Helmuth Rilling conducts the Orchestra of St. Luke's. Jan. 13.

RICCARDO MUTI Even before his acrimonious parting with La Scala in 2005 left him with time on his hands, Mr. Muti had agreed to conduct the New York Philharmonic in four weeks of concerts this season. He likes the orchestra; the orchestra likes him. Are there broader implications in the search for Lorin Maazel's successor as music director? Probably not. As for likes, Mr. Muti surely likes the Russian works he is conducting in the first of these two programs: Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto (with Vadim Repin) and Scriabin's ''Divin Poeme.'' But he loves the Italian works in the second week: Giuseppe Martucci's Piano Concerto in B flat (with Gerhard Oppitz), the ballet music from Verdi's ''Macbeth'' and Respighi's ''Feste Romane.'' Jan. 18-20; Jan. 25-27. Avery Fisher Hall.

CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA RESIDENCY It's a win-win situation, right? Miami gets to hear the Cleveland Orchestra in a concentrated way in its new concert hall, and the Cleveland -- strapped, like most other American orchestras -- gets a solid paying gig. It's that pay that has produced controversy: money that, an influential Miami constituency has argued, would be better spent resuscitating the defunct Florida Philharmonic (which was to have inhabited the new hall), supporting the Miami Symphony or otherwise cultivating indigenous resources. But hearing Franz Welser-Most conduct Beethoven's Ninth Symphony or Mahler's First on a good night in the new hall may ease whatever discontentment remains. Jan. 19-20, 26-27 (also March 16-17). John S. and James L. Knight Concert Hall, (305) 949-6722, clevelandorch.com or carnivalcenter.org.

EDGARD VARESE Alarm Will Sound presents a composer portrait. Jan. 20. Miller Theater. [Article, Page 75.]

DANIEL BARENBOIM In his original guise as pianist, Mr. Barenboim celebrates the 50th anniversary of his Carnegie Hall debut in grand fashion, with the two books of Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier'' on consecutive evenings. Jan. 20-21.

'THE SONG CONTINUES ' Or at least let's hope it does for Marilyn Horne, who has been battling pancreatic cancer. In any case, the Marilyn Horne Foundation and Carnegie Hall present their annual workshop and series of recitals. Jan. 23-26. Zankel Hall, Weill Recital Hall.

FOCUS! 2007 Although Joel Sachs, the director, and the Juilliard School undoubtedly began planning this year's contemporary-music festival, ''The Magyar Legacy: Hungarian Music After Bartok,'' long before the death of Gyorgy Ligeti in June, that landmark passing gives it added point. Other composers represented include some well known in the West (Gyorgy Kurtag and Peter Eotvos) and some not (Laszlo Tihany, Laszlo Vidovsky and Zoltan Jeney). Jan. 26, Jan. 29-Feb. 2. Peter J. Sharp Theater, 155 West 65th Street, (212) 769-7406, juilliard.edu.

KIROV OPERA Having weighed in heavily on Wagner in Orange County, Calif., and on Shostakovich in New York, the Kirov forces turn their attention toward Italy with Rossini's ''Viaggio a Reims'' and Verdi's ''Falstaff'' at the Kennedy Center in Washington. The residency ends with a concert performance of Shostakovich's ''Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District.'' Jan. 27-Feb. 4. (800) 444-1324, kennedy-center.org.

GARRICK OHLSSON And here is a further retreat toward intimacy in Lincoln Center's Beethoven celebration, after the symphonies and the cello sonatas. Mr. Ohlsson plays the first of three programs of piano sonatas, including a couple of favorites: the ''Pathetique'' and the ''Appassionata.'' Jan. 28. Alice Tully Hall (also Feb. 25 at Tully, April 1 at Avery Fisher Hall).

February

ESA-PEKKA SALONEN Mr. Salonen conducts the New York Philharmonic in the premiere of his Piano Concerto, with Yefim Bronfman as soloist, and works by Mussorgsky and Ravel. Feb. 1-3. Avery Fisher Hall. [Article, Page 73.]

MINNESOTA ORCHESTRA In the constant search for ideal chemistry between music director and orchestra, this ensemble seems to have hit on just the right formula with Osmo Vanska, and to have embarked on a renaissance. Mr. Vanska, Finnish himself, is a master of Sibelius, who is amply represented here, and an absolute master of the Fifth Symphony, which ends the first program. And since he and the orchestra are recording all the Beethoven symphonies as their first major project, it is only to be expected that they trot out the Fourth and Fifth here. Feb. 13-14. Carnegie Hall.

BRAHMS FESTIVAL Well, at least it's not the waning Mozart for Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic; that was last season. Or the waxing Beethoven; they did that in 2003. But Mr. Maazel also conducted all the Brahms symphonies and concertos in 2003, with the Bavarian Radio Symphony at Carnegie Hall. True, there is more here: the ''German Requiem'' and the underperformed serenades. Still, the idea is not exactly fresh, and the bigger problem is this: If you had to define Brahms in a word, it would probably be warmth. And if Mr. Maazel, whose conducting often seems antithetical to warmth, cannot muster some here, this could be a long, frustrating slog. That said, the first two programs look great on paper: the two piano concertos, with Emanuel Ax as soloist, and the two serenades. Feb. 14-15; Feb 17, 20 (also April 18-21; May 31-June 1; June 2, 5). Avery Fisher Hall.

'LOST HIGHWAY' Having opened its season with dance, not its usual activity, the Miller Theater now turns to another sideline: opera, though -- with its electronics and video -- not a conventional one. By all accounts, this work by Olga Neuwirth, a composer trained in the Boulez circle, is as inscrutable as the David Lynch film on which it is based. It is performed by the Oberlin Contemporary Music Ensemble. Feb. 23-24.

March

VIENNA PHILHARMONIC With these superbly accomplished and strong-willed players, a conductor's job most of the time is to stay out of the way. Daniel Barenboim knows them well and undoubtedly knows his role just as well. Though inevitably, the repertory is rooted solidly in the Germanic (Schubert, Schumann, Bruckner, Wagner), a Bartok program comes as a nice surprise (with Lang Lang in the Second Piano Concerto). March 2-4. Carnegie Hall.

'THE PIRATES OF PENZANCE' Now that Paul Kellogg has left as general director of the Glimmerglass Opera and is soon to leave the New York City Opera, it will be fascinating to see whether the two companies maintain their close, almost incestuous, ties. Here, at any rate, is a new production of a Gilbert and Sullivan staple by Lillian Groag, fresh from the summer season at Glimmerglass, where it met with slightly modified rapture. Opens March 3. New York State Theater.

LEIPZIG GEWANDHAUS ORCHESTRA This ensemble, as ancient and venerable as they come, nevertheless has something to prove to New York audiences after subpar performances of Brahms two years ago, led by its former music director, Herbert Blomstedt. It returns with more of its central repertory -- Schumann, Liszt, Strauss and Mahler -- conducted by its new music director, Riccardo Chailly. March 5-6. Carnegie Hall.

THOMAS QUASTHOFF Mr. Quasthoff, a bass-baritone firmly rooted in the Germanic repertory, might seem an unlikely choice to perform American songs. But no one who has heard him do ''Ol' Man River'' or ''Swing Low, Sweet Chariot'' -- or for that matter, the Sinatra-owned ''My Way'' -- as an encore will want to miss Mr. Quasthoff's ''American Songbook'' concert, part of his season-long Perspectives series. March 7. Carnegie Hall.

LEON KIRCHNER The Orion String Quartet performs all of his works in the genre, including the premiere of the Fourth, commissioned in part by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. March 7. Alice Tully Hall. chambermusicsociety.org. [Article, Page 73.]

'DIE AGYPTISCHE HELENA' Deborah Voigt follows Salome with another showy Strauss role -- the most beautiful woman in the world, no less, Helen of Troy -- in this rarely performed opera. She sang the role in New York a few years ago and recorded it with Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra, and now the Metropolitan Opera mounts a production for her, directed by David Fielding. (The brochure describes it as postmodern and fanciful; what isn't, these days?) Opens March 15.

BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Bostonians will undoubtedly -- understandably -- be looking forward to the program a week later: a concert performance of Beethoven's opera, ''Fidelio,'' starring Karita Mattila and Johan Botha and conducted by James Levine. But they should not discount this performance of Mahler's Third Symphony, also conducted by Mr. Levine. As New York operagoers well know from his performances of ''Parsifal'' at the Met, the works Mr. Levine loves most, he tends to love to death, clinging desperately to every last note; they become slower and slower, and more and more enthralling and satisfying. The Mahler Third is another of those long, warm baths. March 15-17. Symphony Hall, (888) 266-1200, bso.org.

INGRID FLITER This Argentine pianist's reputation precedes her, as the winner of the $300,000 Gilmore Artist Award this year, from recordings and from a concert at the Caramoor International Music Festival last month. She plays works of Beethoven, Schubert and Chopin. March 21. Zankel Hall.

COLIN DAVIS Concertos, especially Mozart concertos, are not generally seen as showcases for conductors. But that is much of what Sir Colin is about in his programs with the New York Philharmonic this season. In the first week, he conducts Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 19 with Mitsuko Uchida; in the second, No. 27 with Radu Lupu. And on March 28 he conducts both of those works, the Two-Piano Concerto with Ms. Uchida and Mr. Lupu, and Mozart's Symphony No. 32. For the rest he wedges in works by Haydn, Schubert and Sibelius. March 22-24; March 29-31. Avery Fisher Hall.

'LA DONNA DEL LAGO' For this venture into unfamiliar Rossini, the New York City Opera returns to the stars of its highly praised 2004 production of Rossini's ''Ermione,'' Alexandrina Pendatchanska and Barry Banks. Chas Rader-Shieber directs. Opens March 22. New York State Theater.

ARILD REMMEREIT This little-known Norwegian conductor made a mild sensation two seasons ago as a last-minute replacement first for Riccardo Muti with the Filarmonico Della Scala in Milan and then for Christoph von Dohnanyi with the Pittsburgh Symphony. Now New York-area listeners will hear what he can do when he actually has time to rehearse properly. He conducts the New Jersey Symphony in a program of Schumann, Grieg and Stravinsky. March 22-25, 27. Halls in Englewood, Princeton, Red Bank, Morristown and Newark, (800) 255-3476, njsymphony.org.

ST. THOMAS CHOIR OF MEN AND BOYS By now New Yorkers should know to look for this group's presentation of Handel's ''Messiah'' during the holiday season, perennially one of the best. (The dates this year are Dec. 12 and 14.) But an additional highlight is Bach's towering ''St. Matthew Passion,'' with the choir joined by the Musica Angelica Baroque Orchestra of Los Angeles and the Vienna Academy Orchestra, conducted by the noted early-music specialist Martin Haselbock. (This follows a performance on March 20 in Los Angeles.) March 23. St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, (212) 664-9360, saintthomaschurch.org.

'DIE WALKURE' The Washington National Opera adds the second installment of its ''American Ring'' to the ''Rheingold'' of last season. Francesca Zambello directs with an eye toward, in her words, ''American history, mythology, iconography and landscape.'' Placido Domingo, the general director of the company if not the opera world, sings Siegmund, and Heinz Fricke conducts. Opens March 24. Kennedy Center Opera House, (800) 876-7372, dc-opera.org.

NDR SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Christoph von Dohnanyi, who was just what the doctor ordered as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra in the 1980's and 90's, has appeared in the United States mostly as a guest conductor in recent years. But here he shows off the orchestra of North German Radio, which he now directs, in works by Alfred Schnittke and Gyorgy Ligeti as well as in standard Germanic fare. March 26-27. Carnegie Hall.

ST. LOUIS SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA David Robertson conducts two programs with, in the second, the New York premiere of John Adams's ''Doctor Atomic'' Symphony. March 30-31. Carnegie Hall. [Article, Page 73.]

'TURANDOT' No one ever mistook the imperious Turandot for sweet Cinderella. But two sopranos with Cinderella stories of their own -- Andrea Gruber, who made her triumphant return to the Met last year after an extended period of drug abuse, and Erika Sunnegardh, who got her big break at the Met in the spring after long years of waiting on tables -- alternate in the title role in this revival of the Franco Zeffirelli overproduction. Opens March 30. Metropolitan Opera House.

April

'ST. JOHN PASSION' There is a lot of big Bach in the spring, none more promising than this performance by Philippe Herreweghe and the splendid Collegium Vocal Gent Choir and Orchestra. April 8. Alice Tully Hall.

MIKLOS PERENYI If you missed Pieter Wispelwey's performances of Beethoven's complete works for cello and piano in October, or even if you caught it, you will not want to miss these versions by the fine Hungarian cellist Mr. Perenyi and his friend the formidable pianist Andras Schiff, who has been devoting himself largely to Beethoven in recent years. Unlike Mr. Wispelwey, Mr. Perenyi is doing the survey over two nights. April 11-12. 92nd Street Y.

'DER FERNE KLANG' Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra have a good record of setting operatic agendas with their concert performances. They resurrected Dukas's ''Ariane et Barbe-Bleue'' six years before the New York City Opera staged it in 2005 (with Mr. Botstein conducting). And in 2002 they presented Deborah Voigt in Strauss's ''Agyptische Helena,'' as the Met is doing this season. Does this history bode well in New York for the operas of Franz Schreker, which are already making headway in Europe? It may depend on how persuasive a case Mr. Botstein can make for ''Der Ferne Klang.'' April 15. Avery Fisher Hall.

NETHERLANDS BACH SOCIETY The Netherlands has been a hotbed of the modern early-music movement from the start, and this group, founded in 1921, claims to be the oldest early-music ensemble still performing there. Jos van Veldhoven leads it in Bach's Mass in B minor at the Metropolitan Museum. April 18.

'IL TRITTICO' Broadway directors continue to make major inroads at the Met (and this before the Peter Gelb regime has actually taken hold), as Jack O'Brien directs a new production of Puccini's triptych: ''Il Tabarro,'' ''Suor Angelica'' and ''Gianni Schicchi.'' James Levine conducts, and the stars include Maria Guleghina, Salvatore Licitra, Barbara Frittoli, Stephanie Blythe and Alessandro Corbelli. Opens April 20. Metropolitan Opera House.

SACRED MUSIC IN A SACRED SPACE You should by no means wait until this late in the season to check out Kent Tritle's invaluable series at St. Ignatius. But Mr. Tritle ends the season with the church's choir and orchestra in a particularly delightful work by Handel seldom heard in concert, the ''Ode to St. Cecilia,'' to a text by Dryden. Cecilia being the patron saint of music, this is also a celebration of sound, with Handel making the most of ''the trumpet's loud clangor'' and ''the double double double beat of the thundering drum.'' The program also offers a Handel organ concerto and Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 2. April 25. Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, (212) 288-2520, saintignatiusloyola.org.

'LA FINTA GIARDINIERA' You might think that after a year bursting at the seams with Mozart, opera presenters would want to pack away at least the early works for a time. But here is a late flowering of interest from the Juilliard Opera Center. The work should benefit from the youthful good spirits that the students are sure to put into it. April 25, 27, 29. Peter J. Sharp Theater, 155 West 65th Street, (212) 769-7406, juilliard.edu.

CHANTICLEER Ecumenism meets globalism in the premiere of ''And on Earth, Peace,'' a Mass commissioned for this male chorus. The Kyrie is by the Canadian film composer Mychael Danna; the Gloria by the Turkish-American Kamran Ince, to a Sufi text; the Credo by the Israeli-American Shulamit Ran, to a Hebrew text; the Sanctus by the British-born Ivan Moody, in Greek Orthodox style; and the Agnus Dei by the Irishman Michael McGlynn, the composer of ''Riverdance.'' April 26. Metropolitan Museum.

JOHN ADAMS With all the attention focused on Steve Reich's 70th birthday this season, the American Composers Orchestra has happily noticed that Mr. Adams will turn 60 in February. He conducts his own works: ''My Father Knew Charles Ives,'' ''The Wound Dresser'' (with the bass-baritone Eric Owens) and the Violin Concerto (with Leila Josefowicz). April 27. Carnegie Hall.

LOS ANGELES PHILHARMONIC In two concerts interspersed with the imminent ''Tristan Project,'' Esa-Pekka Salonen conducts the New York premiere of his ''Helix,'' Jean-Yves Thibaudet plays Ravel's Piano Concerto for the Left Hand, and Renee Fleming sings songs of Strauss. April 29, May 3. Avery Fisher Hall.

'GOODNIGHT, ALICE' And good luck. Finally, the years of talk give way to action in the renovation of Lincoln Center. Alice Tully Hall is the first to go under the knife, but before it does, David Robertson leads the Juilliard Orchestra in a serenade evening, ending, appropriately, with Haydn's ''Farewell'' Symphony. April 30.

May

'The TRISTAN PROJECT' A pity. This venture by Great Performers at Lincoln Center was to have brought the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue into the New York concert whirl, but the building's audience amenities have been deemed not ready for prime time. Instead, the project has been wedged into the busy schedule of the hapless Avery Fisher Hall, losing in the process much of its reason for being: three evenings juxtaposing separate acts of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' with music of Debussy. So it boils down to two semistaged performances of the opera, directed by Peter Sellars and with video by Bill Viola. Esa-Pekka Salonen conducts the Los Angeles Philharmonic, and Alan Woodrow and Christine Brewer sing the title roles. Here's hoping that Lincoln Center (or someone) will persist in bringing the armory into musical play sooner rather than later. May 2, 5.

'ORFEO ED EURIDICE' As if to acknowledge that Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died at the height of her vocal and dramatic powers in July, is irreplaceable, the Metropolitan Opera has turned over her role of Orfeo in a new production of Gluck's opera not to another mezzo-soprano but to a countertenor, David Daniels. The production, directed and choreographed by Mark Morris, with costumes by Isaac Mizrahi, is now dedicated to Ms. Hunt Lieberson. The cast also includes Lisa Milne as Euridice and Heidi Grant Murphy as Amor. James Levine conducts. But all of that for only four performances? Happily, one of them, on May 5, is on the radio. Opens May 2.

BETHLEHEM BACH FESTIVAL The Bach Choir of Bethlehem, Pa., which presents a festival every spring, celebrated its 100th anniversary in 1998. Now comes the centennial of the festival itself, with Bach's Mass in B minor and ''St. Matthew Passion,'' and special features including an appearance by the Paul Taylor Dance Company. You may hear better Bach performances, but you won't hear more heartfelt ones. May 3-13. Packer Memorial Church and other locations, (888) 743-3100, bach.org.

JORDI SAVALL Mr. Savall, who has built a wide-ranging career on an unlikely virtuoso vehicle, the viola da gamba, returns to his roots in two programs centering on that instrument. His New York concerts with expanded forces have been highlights of recent seasons. The programs here, though smaller in scale, promise to be no less compelling. May 9-10. Metropolitan Museum.

DEBORAH VOIGT There wasn't much information for this recital at press time: simply, works by Bernstein, Mozart, Respighi, Strauss and Verdi. It won't matter to Ms. Voigt's many fans. Brian Zeger is the pianist. May 11. Carnegie Hall.

'ELIJAH' Since Robert Spano and now Michael Christie have revolutionized the Brooklyn Philharmonic, hardly anything comes as a surprise -- except that is, for anything mildly reactionary. Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' has long suffered a bad rap for the wave of fusty oratorios it inspired in Victorian England. It remains a great work, and if anyone can bring it to life for a trendy modern audience, it should be Mr. Christie. May 12. Brooklyn Academy of Music.

CHARLES ROSEN The venerable pianist, lecturer, critic and scholar celebrates his 80th birthday (May 5) several days late with his idea of a good time: grappling with Beethoven's last three piano sonatas in performance and discussion. Formidable party fare indeed. May 13. 92nd Street Y.

SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Michael Tilson Thomas's first concert is a felicitous mix: the Tchaikovsky-Stravinsky ''Baiser de la Fee,'' Stravinsky's Symphony in Three Movements and Tchaikovsky's underestimated First Symphony. The second, with works of Copland, Mahler and Strauss, works less well as a program, but the performances should carry the day. May 17-18. Carnegie Hall.

'WALL TO WALL OPERA: 1607-2007' Usually it is a single composer who gets the marathon treatment, and many of the musical choices are predictable. But here it is an entire art form, which could occupy days, weeks, months. Where to start? The event runs from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. and is free. May 19. Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400, symphonyspace.org.

FORT WORTH OPERA FESTIVAL The Fort Worth Opera has changed its spots: it is now an annual festival, and the highlight of the first outing is the premiere of Thomas Pasatieri's ''Frau Margot,'' opening on June 2 and starring Lauren Flanigan. May 19-June 10. Bass Performance Hall, (877) 396-7372, fwopera.org.

EMERSON STRING QUARTET For the Beethoven season, the grandest of grand finales: having led an 11-day professional training workshop on the Beethoven string quartets as part of their Perspectives series, the Emerson players go on to perform all 16 of them in programs larded with works by other composers, from Bach, Haydn and Mozart to Ives, Wolfgang Rihm and Kaija Saariaho. And for an encore? May 31; June 3, 5, 7, 10, 12, 14, 17. Carnegie Hall.

June

BOSTON EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL Paul O'Dette and Stephen Stubbs are the artistic directors of this granddaddy of American early-music festivals, a teeming biennial event now in its 14th season. The centerpiece consists of five performances of a new production of Lully's opera ''Psyche,'' with stage direction by Gilbert Blin. Carolyn Sampson sings the title role, and Karina Gauvin sings Venus. June 11-17. Cutler Majestic Theater at Emerson College and elsewhere, (617) 661-1812, bemf.org.

PUB-DATE: September 10, 2006
Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; THE NEW SEASON THEATER; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 615 words

HEADLINE: Antiques That Seem New Again

BYLINE: By CHARLES ISHERWOOD

 BODY:
THEATER has always been in the business of recycling and renovation. Even ye olde Greeks were retelling oft-told tales. But these days, as revivals seem to outnumber new plays, at least on Broadway, it is easy to point to their preponderance as evidence of the business's superannuated condition. And yet the ability to revisit classic -- or even just old -- works is one of the major glories of the theater. 
 Admit too that even stuffy old Broadway has a better track record when it comes to ''remakes'' than Hollywood, which cannot manage even to improve on cheesy sitcoms when it goes foraging in the past. Three notable productions this fall exemplify different approaches to the craft of theatrical restoration. 
The Roundabout Theater Company tends to play it sensibly, safely and respectably. The formula is simple: Take a classic, add a few stars and a director of stature, and mix. 
 This fall the company's slate includes a welcome revival of Shaw's twilight comedy-drama ''Heartbreak House,'' with a cast of reliable names like Philip Bosco, Laila Robins and Swoosie Kurtz as well as Lily Rabe, the daughter of David Rabe and Jill Clayburgh, who is displaying an impressive devotion to the stage at a time when most young actors have their sights set elsewhere. The director is Robin Lefevre. And the Roundabout deserves credit for its allegiance to Shaw, particularly as the 150th anniversary of his birth year comes to a close.
 Another season, another Stephen Sondheim revival? No reason to complain when they are exhilarating reconsiderations like John Doyle's ''Sweeney Todd'' from last year, which boiled the ghoulish musical down to its firm bones and rattled them beautifully. The satisfying partnership of Mr. Doyle and Mr. Sondheim returns this season with a new look at ''Company,'' from 1970. 
 Mr. Doyle, who won a Tony for directing ''Sweeney,'' is once again using an economy of means to unearth new riches in a much-revived musical. In literal terms that means that once again the cast is doubling as the orchestra.
 But the presumption that Mr. Doyle's unique musical methodology is merely a gimmick is refuted by this sleek, compelling production, which I saw at its premiere last season at the Playhouse in the Park in Cincinnati. Despite its treasured score, the rap on ''Company,'' in which the roving eye of a bachelor turning 30 traces the fault lines in the marriages of his friends, is that it has been permanently stuck in its period, as a sort of musical comedy answer to ''That 70's Show.'' But Mr. Doyle's production, which stars a magnetic Raul Esparza as the chronically unattached Bobby, cleanly ushers it into a timeless present tense without playing fast and loose with George Furth's book.
 ''My Deah,'' a new comedy by John Epperson, better known as the voiceless drag diva Lypsinka, typifies the reliable theatrical appeal of taking a fiendishly irreverent approach to a piece of antique dramaturgy -- in this case, Euripides' revered ''Medea.'' 
 I attended a reading of Mr. Epperson's spoof sometime around 210 B.C., it seems to me, and have been baffled by its failure to be produced in New York. Treading confidently a path forged by the respected auteurs Charles Ludlam and Charles Busch (possibly in similar heels), Mr. Epperson sends up the original by transplanting it to the Deep South. 
 Lypsinka herself will not be appearing -- a voiceless Medea is inconceivable -- but Nancy Opel, a dab hand at low-down comedy, should be perfect casting for the title role, a woman who makes your garden-variety steel magnolia look like a shrinking violet. The production, directed by Mark Waldrop, comes courtesy of the Abingdon Theater Company.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Paperback Row; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 768 words

BYLINE: By Ihsan Taylor

 BODY:
LUNAR PARK, by Bret Easton Ellis. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.95.) Ellis's phantasmagorical tale is narrated by a writer -- named Bret Easton Ellis -- whose first novel, ''Less Than Zero,'' made him a literary celebrity in the 1980's. Leaving behind the shallow glitter of Manhattan, Bret strikes out for the suburbs, marries the movie-star mother of his son and plods through a teaching job at a local college. But bourgeois malaise turns to terror when Bret is stalked by the ghost of his alcoholic father and by his infamous creation, the deranged Patrick Bateman of ''American Psycho.'' In the Book Review, A. O. Scott called ''Lunar Park'' a ''tale of wild chemical and sexual excess'' that is ''shot through with longing.''
JOHN KENNETH GALBRAITH: His Life, His Politics, His Economics, by Richard Parker. (University of Chicago, $22.50.) Parker's comprehensive biography describes how Galbraith (1908-2006), once the most famous economist in America, became a public intellectual, honing his famously aphoristic style. It is also, thanks to Galbraith's longevity and his battles with so many other economic thinkers, a fine one-volume history of economic thought in the 20th century. 
 GOD'S GYM, by John Edgar Wideman. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $12.95.) The 10 stories in this challenging collection push the boundaries of narrative and form, as Wideman wrestles with big-deal subjects: love and death and the mysteries of time. In ''The Silence of Thelonius Monk,'' the author imagines Monk speaking to him from beyond the grave: ''Who said I retreated to silence? Retreat hell. I was attacking in another direction.''
 GARBAGE LAND: On the Secret Trail of Trash, by Elizabeth Royte. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.99.) Royte, whose previous book, ''The Tapir's Morning Bath,'' followed researchers in the tropical rain forest, here tracks an assortment of garbage collectors, recyclers and sewage treaters, beginning with the men who pick up the stuff at her curb in Brooklyn on trash day. Why? To see how much damage she is personally doing in the grand scheme of things and how she might minimize it. As she makes her rounds, Royte encounters colorful characters and cites a blizzard of studies, statistics and experts to corroborate the assessment of a former New York sanitation commissioner: ''In the end, the garbage will win.''
 HALF BROKEN THINGS, by Morag Joss. (Delta, $13.) The 2003 winner of the British Crime Writers Association's Silver Dagger Award, Joss's story of psychological suspense revolves around a gracious country home left in the care of a professional housesitter, 64-year-old Jean Wade. Without realizing she has suffered a psychotic break, Jean plays lady of the manor, ensnaring two equally lost souls -- a clever thief and a pregnant teenager -- in her fantasy.
 PORNIFIED: How Pornography Is Damaging Our Lives, Our Relationships, and Our Families, by Pamela Paul. (Owl/Holt, $15.) Paul, a journalist and the author of ''The Starter Marriage and the Future of Matrimony,'' argues that an increased supply of pornography -- fueled by the often violent porn on the Internet -- is creating sex addicts and splintering families.
 THE PAINTED DRUM, by Louise Erdrich. (Harper Perennial, $13.95.) A ceremonial drum magically linked to children and death is the centerpiece of Erdrich's latest novel set among the Ojibwa. While appraising the estate of a family descended from an Indian trader, Faye Travers, herself one-quarter Ojibwa, discovers the object and vows to return it to the North Dakota reservation where it was created. The novel, told from various perspectives, follows the drum's multigenerational history. Our reviewer, Benjamin Markovits, said Erdrich's ''fictionalized version of the real Ojibwa tribe is a brilliant creation: it possesses the instantly persuasive strangeness of something faithful to life.''
 THE SHAME OF THE NATION: The Restoration of Apartheid Schooling in America, by Jonathan Kozol. (Three Rivers, $14.95.) Over a five-year period, Kozol visited approximately 60 schools in 11 states, finding children of the poor and minorities trapped, almost uniformly, in old schools that are overcrowded, in poor repair, with scanty teaching materials, and staffed by generally underqualified teachers.
 TRUE STORY: Murder, Memoir, Mea Culpa, by Michael Finkel. (Harper Perennial, $14.95.) Finkel, a disgraced freelance journalist, recounts the bizarre story of the murderer who assumed his identity, and comes to terms with his own career (in 2002 he was caught inventing a character in an article for The New York Times Magazine). Ihsan Taylor

An entry in the Paperback Row column on Sept. 10 about ''God's Gym,'' a story collection by John Edgar Wideman, misspelled part of one story's title, the given name of a jazz musician who figures in the plot. It is ''The Silence of Thelonious Monk,'' not Thelonius.

 Other recent books of particular interest

GALLATIN CANYON: Stories, by Thomas McGuane. (Knopf, $24.) McGuane's portraits of American manhood have the capacity to astonish.

HEADLINE: TROPICAL VILLA, ANYONE?

BYLINE: By Camille Sweeney

 BODY:
Approximately 20 percent of all American homeowners now own second houses, according to the National Association of Realtors. This does not include the number of second homes abroad; that figure has yet to be calculated. But Delores Conway, director of the Casden Real Estate Economics Forecast at the University of Southern California's Lusk Center for Real Estate, says it's significant and increasing. ''There is a very broad trend that shows that Americans, especially baby boomers, are pursuing unique living experiences,'' she says, ''and vacation homes outside the country are part of that trend.'' Still, prospective buyers need to be aware of local laws, customs and real estate regulations. Here is a guide to some of the most dynamic foreign second-home markets.
BAHAMAS
 Vital stats: 
 The Bahamas is a 100,000-square-mile archipelago with 700 islands, including uninhabited cays and large rocks. Approximately 20 percent of the islands' homes are foreign owned, and the majority of foreign owners are Americans. Available properties range from a condo in the casino haven of Paradise Island to a remote island bungalow on Eleuthera. 
 Travel time: 
 To Nassau by air, 3 hours from New York, 312 hours from Chicago, 7 hours from Los Angeles.
 Types of ownership: 
 Leasehold estates, where a buyer does not actually own property but obtains a recorded long-term lease, and freehold titles, where a buyer owns property, with a title in his or her name. 
 Financials:
 Foreign buyers can make transactions in American dollars but must register with the Central Bank of the Bahamas. In the event of a sale in Bahamian dollars, only those owners who registered their initial purchase can convert money back to American dollars to take out 
 of the country. Local homeowners' insurance is recommended. There are no capital gains or inheritance taxes on homes. But income made on a rental property in the Bahamas will be taxed in the United States. 
 Restrictions:
 There are no restrictions on buying residential homes, but if you are buying an investment property with the intention of developing or leasing it, you must apply for government approval.
 PANAMA 
 Vital stats:
 Panama has an area of about 30,000 square miles, and it borders Costa Rica and Colombia. The foreign-homeowner market is dominated by Americans, especially retirees, but lately a younger American demographic is investing in everything from pieds-a-terre in Panama City to beachfront condos on the coast and single-family homes in the highlands.
 Travel time: 
 To Panama City by air: 5 hours from New York, 712 hours from Chicago (via Atlanta), 612 hours from Los Angeles.
 Types of ownership: 
 Foreign buyers are able to purchase only property that is titled (the majority of Panamanian residences are). Foreign homeowners are 
 granted the same rights as Panamanian homeowners to transfer and develop property. 
 Financials:
 Though local mortgages are available, many foreign purchases of residences are all-cash American-dollar deals. Local homeowners' insurance is recommended. There is a capital gains tax on the sale of a home, but property taxes are low (about 2 percent). There is also a territorial tax on income made from a rental property.
 Restrictions:
 Foreign buyers are not eligible to purchase the property on many of Panama's islands. And foreign-owned property must be at least 6.2 miles inland from Panama's borders. 
 MEXICO
 Vital stats:
 Mexico has long been a second-home market for Americans, primarily from the Southwest and California, who invest in properties like renovated colonial homes in central Mexico, condos on the Mayan Riviera and villas in the rapidly developing high-end resort communities of the Pacific Coast. 
 Travel time: 
 To Mexico City by air: 5 hours from New York, 4 hours from Chicago, 312 hours from Los Angeles. 
 Types of ownership: 
 Mexico's Constitution stipulates two kinds of ownership: freehold title ownership and a fideicomiso, or long-term trust that lasts for 50 years and is renewable in perpetuity. 
 Financials:
 Though local mortgages are becoming more readily available to foreigners, foreign purchase of Mexican residential property is typically done in all-cash American-dollar deals. There is generally no inheritance tax, and compared with the United States, Mexico's property taxes are very low (about 0.3 percent). 
 Restrictions:
 Mexico's Constitution bans foreigners from freehold ownership within 30 miles of the coastline or 60 miles of any border. 
 BRITISH COLUMBIA
 Vital stats:
 Canada's westernmost province is made up of nearly 370,000 square miles of rivers, lakes, mountains, beaches, plains and islands, with a climate temperate enough for a visitor to golf and ski on the same day. American buyers -- especially from the Northwest, California, Texas and Florida -- have increasingly been looking here for second homes, ranging from a family retreat on Okanagan 
 Lake, in British Columbia's wine 
 country, to a town house in Victoria, 
 on Vancouver Island.
 Travel time: 
 To Vancouver by air: 512 hours from New York, 412 hours from Chicago, 212 hours from Los Angeles.
 Types of ownership: 
 Freehold is the most common type of ownership. 
 Financials:
 Typically, a foreigner will either pay all cash in Canadian dollars or obtain a local mortgage on the property requiring an average down payment of 30 to 35 percent. There are taxes on buying real estate, as well as on property, capital gains, inheritance and income earned on a property. 
 Restrictions:
 There are no significant restrictions on what foreigners can buy in British Columbia. 
 ITALY
 Vital stats:
 Italy has long been a popular vacation destination for both Europeans and Americans. More recently, it has also become a popular second-home locale for Americans, particularly Tuscany, Liguria and Lombardy, along with the lake district, the Alps, the Isle of Capri, the Amalfi coast, Sardinia and Sicily. 
 Travel time:
 To Rome by air: 8 hours from New York, 9 hours from Chicago, 1512 hours from Los Angeles.
 Types of ownership:
 Most Italian properties are freehold.
 Financials:
 A 10 percent down payment is typically required for the purchase of a 
 property, and a preliminary contract must be signed and overseen by a notary. Mortgages are available through local institutions, but generally foreign lenders will offer better terms. A sale is complete when the full payment is made and a final deed or conveyance of transfer is signed before a notary. Currency other than euros used in a sale must be officially documented should a seller wish to repatriate the proceeds. Income tax from a rental property is high in Italy (from 10 to 60 percent). There are also property taxes, inheritance taxes and,in some cases, capital gains taxes.
 Restrictions:
 There are no restrictions on foreign ownership.
 Dubai
 Vital stats:
 Dubai is the second-largest of the seven states that make up the United Arab Emirates. With an area of 1,500 square miles, Dubai is a business hub of the Middle East situated on the banks of the Dubai Creek, an inlet of the Persian Gulf. Recently, it has also become a high-end exotic destination for Europeans and Americans. Residential development is brisk. 
 Travel time: 
 To Dubai: 13 hours from New York, 
 1612 hours from Chicago, 18 hours from Los Angeles. 
 Types of ownership: 
 Earlier this year, new laws were announced that allow foreigners full ownership of freehold land and property. 
 Financials:
 Investments can be made using a United States bank account with funds transferred directly to the developer. But it is generally recommended that 
 buyers have a foreign exchange account to get the best rates on money transfers. Owning a property in Dubai entitles you and a spouse to residency visas, which allow you to have bank accounts and to incorporate in Dubai, where there is no income tax. 
 Restrictions:
 There are still certain freehold zones where only nationals can own property. Camille Sweeney
